<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Oceania</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Geographical region in the Pacific Ocean</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the geographical region. For the continent, see <a href="/wiki/Australia_(continent)" title="Australia (continent)">Australia (continent)</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Oceania_(disambiguation)" title="Oceania (disambiguation)">Oceania (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"South West Pacific" redirects here. For the 1943 Australian film, see <a href="/wiki/South_West_Pacific_(film)" title="South West Pacific (film)"><i>South West Pacific</i> (film)</a>. For the World War II military command, see <a href="/wiki/South_West_Pacific_Area_(command)" title="South West Pacific Area (command)">South West Pacific Area (command)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

orthographic projection of geopolitical Oceania</div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Area</th><td class="infobox-data">8,525,989 km<sup>2</sup> (3,291,903 sq mi)</td></tr><tr><th </div> <div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: center; font-size: 95%;">
<div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; font-size: 100%; text-align: left;"><div>Associated (2) (<a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_in_Oceania#Non-United_Nations_member_states" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Oceania">list</a>)</div></div>
<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit; text-align: left; list-style: none; margin-left: 0;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> <span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Flag_of_the_Cook_Islands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Cook_Islands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Flag_of_the_Cook_Islands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Cook_Islands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Flag_of_the_Cook_Islands.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Cook_Islands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a> (<a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>)</span> </li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> <span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Flag_of_Niue.svg/23px-Flag_of_Niue.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Flag_of_Niue.svg/35px-Flag_of_Niue.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Flag_of_Niue.svg/46px-Flag_of_Niue.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Niue" title="Niue">Niue</a> (<a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Dependencies</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: center; font-size: 95%;">

margin: 0">* <span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="550" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Flag_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Flag_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Flag_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Northern_Mariana_Islands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands" title="Northern Mariana Islands">Northern Mariana Islands</a> </li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0">* <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States"><img alt="United States" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Palmyra_Atoll" title="Palmyra Atoll">Palmyra Atoll</a> </li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0">* <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States"><img alt="United States" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Wake_Island" title="Wake Island">Wake Island</a></li></ul>
</div>
<div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: center; font-size: 95%;">
<div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; font-size: 100%; text-align: left;"><div>Internal (6) (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-sovereign_territories_in_Oceania" title="Non-sovereign territories in Oceania">list</a>)</div></div>
<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit; text-align: left; list-style: none; margin-left: 0;"><li style="line-height: inherit; </div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Languages</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: center; font-size: 95%;">

<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit; text-align: left; list-style: none; margin-left: 0;"><li style="line-height: inherit; </div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/UN_M49" title="UN M49">UN M49 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><code>009</code> – Oceania<br/><code>001</code> – <a href="/wiki/World" title="World">World</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Oceania</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">UK</a>: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span><span title="/ʃ/: 'sh' in 'shy'">ʃ</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span></span>-,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>-/</a></span></span>, <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">US</a>: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span><span title="/ʃ/: 'sh' in 'shy'">ʃ</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Oceania.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/58/En-us-Oceania.ogg" title="En-us-Oceania.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>, <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>-/</a></span></span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pronun_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-pronun-5">[5]</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Region" title="Region">geographical region</a> that includes <a href="/wiki/Australasia" title="Australasia">Australasia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Micronesia" title="Micronesia">Micronesia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polynesia" title="Polynesia">Polynesia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aging_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-aging-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldatlas_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldatlas-7">[7]</a></sup> Spanning the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_hemisphere" title="Eastern hemisphere">Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western</a> hemispheres, Oceania is estimated to have a land area of 8,525,989 square kilometres (3,291,903 sq mi) and a population of around 44.5 million as of 2021. When compared with the other <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continents</a>, the region of Oceania is the smallest in land area and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_continents_and_continental_subregions_by_population" title="List of continents and continental subregions by population">second smallest in population</a> after <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>. Its major population centres are <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brisbane" title="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Perth" title="Perth">Perth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">Auckland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adelaide" title="Adelaide">Adelaide</a> and <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a>.
</p><p>Oceania has a diverse mix of economies from the <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">highly developed</a> and globally competitive <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">financial markets</a> of <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaiʻi</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>, which rank high in <a href="/wiki/Quality_of_life" title="Quality of life">quality of life</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worlda_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-worlda-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herita_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-herita-9">[9]</a></sup> to the much <a href="/wiki/Least_developed_countries" title="Least developed countries">less developed economies</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kiribati" title="Kiribati">Kiribati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Western_New_Guinea" title="Western New Guinea">Western New Guinea</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imforg_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-imforg-10">[10]</a></sup> while also including <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">medium-sized economies</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_in_the_Pacific_Ocean" title="List of islands in the Pacific Ocean">Pacific islands</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-undporg_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-undporg-11">[11]</a></sup> The largest and most populous <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_in_Oceania" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Oceania">country in Oceania</a> is Australia, and the largest city is Sydney.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dfatgov_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-dfatgov-12">[12]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Puncak_Jaya" title="Puncak Jaya">Puncak Jaya</a> in Papua is the highest peak in Oceania at 4,884 m (16,024 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-modern283_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-modern283-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first settlers of Australia, New Guinea, and the large islands just to the east arrived more than 60,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Oceania was <a href="/wiki/Exploration_of_the_Pacific" title="Exploration of the Pacific">first explored by Europeans</a> from the 16th century onward. Portuguese explorers, between 1512 and 1526, reached the <a href="/wiki/Tanimbar_Islands" title="Tanimbar Islands">Tanimbar Islands</a>, some of the <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Islands" title="Caroline Islands">Caroline Islands</a> and west <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>. On his first voyage in the 18th century, <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">James Cook</a>, who later arrived at the highly developed <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands" title="Hawaiian Islands">Hawaiʻian Islands</a>, went to <a href="/wiki/Tahiti" title="Tahiti">Tahiti</a> and followed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Australia" title="Eastern Australia">east coast of Australia</a> for the first time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-foundi_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-foundi-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Europeans_in_Oceania" title="Europeans in Oceania">arrival of European settlers</a> in subsequent centuries resulted in a significant alteration in the social and political landscape of Oceania. The <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Oceania#World_War_II" title="Military history of Oceania">Pacific theatre</a> saw major action during the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">Second World War</a>, mainly between <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied powers</a> the <a href="/wiki/United_States_home_front_during_World_War_II" title="United States home front during World War II">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_(U.S._insular_area)" title="Commonwealth (U.S. insular area)">US Commonwealth</a> at the time) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australia_in_World_War_II" title="Australia in World War II">Australia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis power</a> <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japan</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Rock_art" title="Rock art">rock art</a> of <a href="/wiki/Aboriginal_Australians" title="Aboriginal Australians">Aboriginal Australians</a> is the longest continuously practiced artistic tradition in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oceanart_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-oceanart-16">[16]</a></sup> Most Oceanian countries are <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracies</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">tourism</a> being a large source of income for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands" title="Pacific Islands">Pacific Islands</a> nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newpol162_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-newpol162-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Definitions_and_extent">Definitions and extent</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Definitions and extent">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Characteristics">Characteristics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Characteristics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="520" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg/300px-Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg/450px-Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg/600px-Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oceania_UN_Geoscheme_Regions.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Subregions of Oceania.</div></div></div>
<p>Definitions of Oceania vary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asianpacific_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-asianpacific-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldatlas_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-worldatlas-7">[7]</a></sup> The broadest definition of Oceania encompasses the many islands between mainland <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aging_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-aging-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harv_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-harv-21">[21]</a></sup> The island nation of <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> is the only piece of land in the area which is large enough to be considered a continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> The culture of the people who lived on these islands was often distinct from that of Asia and <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era" title="Pre-Columbian era">pre-Columbian</a> America, hence a lack of association with either.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edu_au_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-edu_au-24">[24]</a></sup> Before <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Europe" title="Ethnic groups in Europe">Europeans</a> arrived in the area, the sea barrier shielded Australia and south central Pacific islands from cultural influences that spread through large continental landmasses and adjacent islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edu_au_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-edu_au-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cam_uk_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-cam_uk-25">[25]</a></sup> The islands of the <a href="/wiki/Malay_Archipelago" title="Malay Archipelago">Malay Archipelago</a>, north of Australia, mainly lie on the <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf" title="Continental shelf">continental shelf</a> of Asia, and their inhabitants had more exposure to mainland Asian culture as a result of this closer proximity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edu_au_24-2"><a href="#cite_note-edu_au-24">[24]</a></sup> The island of <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> similarly lies on the continental shelf of Asia, with their inhabitants historically having had exchange with mainland Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>The geographer <a href="/wiki/Conrad_Malte-Brun" title="Conrad Malte-Brun">Conrad Malte-Brun</a> coined the <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> expression <i>Terres océaniques</i> (Oceanic lands) <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1804,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OED_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-OED-27">[27]</a></sup> then in 1814 another French cartographer, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Adrien-Hubert_Bru%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Adrien-Hubert Brué (page does not exist)">Adrien-Hubert Brué</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrien-Hubert_Bru%C3%A9" title="fr:Adrien-Hubert Brué">fr</a>]</span>, coined from this expression the shorter "Océanie" putting it on a map, « <i>Océanie, ou cinquième partie du monde, comprenant l'archipel d'Asie, l'Australasie et la Polynésie (ou le continent de la Nouvelle Hollande et les îles du Grand Océan)</i> ».<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> <i>Océanie</i> derives from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a> word <i lang="la"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/oceanus#Latin" title="wikt:oceanus">oceanus</a></i>, and this from the <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> word <span lang="grc"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BD%A0%CE%BA%CE%B5%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%8C%CF%82#Ancient_Greek" title="wikt:ὠκεανός">ὠκεανός</a></span> (<i>ōkeanós</i>), "ocean". The term <i>Oceania</i> is used because, unlike the other continental groupings, it is the ocean that links the parts of the region together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pacifi30_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-pacifi30-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Quotation needed from source to verify. (September 2018)">need quotation to verify</span></a></i>]</sup> John Eperjesi's 2005 book <i>The Imperialist Imaginary: Visions of Asia and the Pacific in American Culture</i> says that it has "been used by <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Western_civilization" title="Western civilization">western</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cartographer" title="Cartographer">cartographers</a> since the mid-nineteenth century to give order to the complexities of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Paciﬁc</a> area."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The <i>Handbook of Religion</i> (2014) states that it was "introduced by westerners" and in the 19th century helped describe "a sociopolitical reality of the islands of [the] Pacific and Australia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> In the 19th century, many geographers divided up Oceania into mostly racially based subdivisions; <i>Australasia</i>, <i>Malaysia</i> (encompassing the Malay Archipelago), <i>Melanesia</i>, <i>Micronesia</i> and <i>Polynesia</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corn_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-corn-32">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-missionary_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-missionary-33">[33]</a></sup> Australian sociologist Nichole Georgeou states, "while initially these sub-categories meant little to Pacific Islanders, today they form the basis of very real cultural, social and political identities."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> The 2011 book <i>Maritime Adaptations of the Pacific</i>, by Richard W. Casteel and Jean-Claude Passeron, states that, "for the purpose of <a href="/wiki/Anthropology" title="Anthropology">anthropology</a>, Oceania has long been a continent like Africa, Asia and America."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Scottish geographer <a href="/wiki/John_Bartholomew" title="John Bartholomew">John Bartholomew</a> wrote in 1873 that, "the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a> consists of <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>, and the peninsula of <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> attached to it. These divisions [are] generally themselves spoken as continents, and to them has been added another, embracing the large island of Australia and numerous others in the [Pacific] Ocean, under the name of Oceania. There are thus six great divisions of the earth — <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, Asia, <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>, North America, South America and Oceania."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> In his 1879 book <i>Australasia</i>, British naturalist <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace" title="Alfred Russel Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a> commented that, "Oceania is the word often used by continental geographers to describe the great world of islands we are now entering upon" and that "Australia forms its central and most important feature."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-austral_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-austral-37">[37]</a></sup> He did not explicitly label Oceania a continent in the book, but did note that it was one of the six major divisions of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-austral_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-austral-37">[37]</a></sup> <i>The Oxford Handbook of World History</i> (2011) describes the areas encompassed in Oceania as being "afterthoughts in world history texts, lumped together and included at the end of global surveys as areas largely marginal to the main events of world history."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> The 1995 book <i>The Pacific Island States</i>, by Australian author Stephen Henningham, claims that Oceania in its broadest sense "incorporates all the insular areas between the Americas and Asia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>In some countries, such as <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">Costa Rica</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> or <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, Oceania is regarded as a continent in the sense that it is "one of the parts of the world", and the concept of Australia as a continent is not used.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Prior to the 1950s, Australia was not normally viewed as one of the world's continents in <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>-speaking countries, but rather as a large island, such as <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lewis32b_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-lewis32b-41">[41]</a></sup> In her 1961 book <i>The United States and the Southwest Pacific</i>, American author <a href="/wiki/C._Hartley_Grattan" title="C. Hartley Grattan">Clinton Hartley Grattan</a> commented that, "the use of the word Oceania to cover Australia, New Zealand, and the [Pacific] islands now has a slightly old-fashioned flavor."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Australia is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands_Forum" title="Pacific Islands Forum">Pacific Islands Forum</a> in 1971, and at times has been interpreted as the largest Pacific island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-smh_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-smh-43">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> For example, <a href="/wiki/Tony_deBrum" title="Tony deBrum">Tony deBrum</a>, Foreign Minister for the Marshall Islands, stated in 2014, "not only [is Australia] our big brother down south, Australia is a member of the Pacific Islands Forum and Australia is a Pacific island, a big island, but a Pacific island."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-smh_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-smh-43">[43]</a></sup> Some geographers group the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Plate" title="Australian Plate">Australian continental plate</a> with other islands in the Pacific into a physical continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic" title="National Geographic">National Geographic</a></i> states that the term Oceania "establishes the Pacific Ocean as the defining characteristic of the continent."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Others have labelled it as the "liquid continent."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The Pacific Ocean itself has been labelled as a "continent of islands", and contains approximately 25,000, which is more than all the other major oceans combined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Oceania's subregions of <a href="/wiki/Australasia" title="Australasia">Australasia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Micronesia" title="Micronesia">Micronesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polynesia" title="Polynesia">Polynesia</a> cover two major plates; the Australian Plate (also known as the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">Pacific Plate</a>, in addition to two minor plates; the <a href="/wiki/Nazca_Plate" title="Nazca Plate">Nazca Plate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea_Plate" title="Philippine Sea Plate">Philippine Sea Plate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birds_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-birds-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plates_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-plates-53">[53]</a></sup> The Australian Plate includes Australia, <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birds_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-birds-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plates_53-1"><a href="#cite_note-plates-53">[53]</a></sup> The Pacific Plate covers the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a> and parts of New Zealand, as well as Micronesia (excluding the westernmost islands near the Philippine Sea Plate) and Polynesia (excluding <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birds_52-2"><a href="#cite_note-birds-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plates_53-2"><a href="#cite_note-plates-53">[53]</a></sup> The Nazca Plate, which includes Easter Island, neighbors the <a href="/wiki/South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American Plate</a>, and is still considered to be a separate tectonic plate, despite only containing a handful of islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birds_52-3"><a href="#cite_note-birds-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plates_53-3"><a href="#cite_note-plates-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Boundaries">Boundaries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Boundaries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information on Oceania borders: <a href="/wiki/Boundaries_between_the_continents_of_Earth" title="Boundaries between the continents of Earth">Boundaries between the continents of Earth</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">List of transcontinental countries</a></div>
<p>Islands at the geographic extremes of Oceania are generally considered to be the <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">Bonin Islands</a>, a politically integral part of Japan; <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaiʻi</a>, a state of the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>; <a href="/wiki/Clipperton_Island" title="Clipperton Island">Clipperton Island</a>, a possession of <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Juan_Fern%C3%A1ndez_Islands" title="Juan Fernández Islands">Juan Fernández Islands</a>, belonging to Chile; and <a href="/wiki/Macquarie_Island" title="Macquarie Island">Macquarie Island</a>, belonging to Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-class_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-class-54">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausgov_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausgov-56">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-realm_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-realm-58">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="United_Nations_interpretation">United Nations interpretation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: United Nations interpretation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN) has its own geopolitical definition of Oceania, but this consists of discrete political entities, and so excludes the Bonin Islands, Hawaiʻi, Clipperton Island and the Juan Fernández Islands, along with Easter Island — which was annexed by Chile in 1888.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> It is used in statistical reports, by the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a>, and by many atlases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis_1997_32_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis_1997_32-62">[62]</a></sup> The UN categorizes Oceania, and by extension the Pacific area, as one of the major continental divisions of the world, along with Africa, Asia, Europe and the Americas. Their definition includes <a href="/wiki/American_Samoa" title="American Samoa">American Samoa</a>, Australia and their <a href="/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia" title="States and territories of Australia">external territories</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia" title="Federated States of Micronesia">Federated States of Micronesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, Fiji, <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kiribati" title="Kiribati">Kiribati</a>, the Marshall Islands, <a href="/wiki/Nauru" title="Nauru">Nauru</a>, New Caledonia, New Zealand, <a href="/wiki/Niue" title="Niue">Niue</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands" title="Northern Mariana Islands">Northern Mariana Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a>, Papua New Guinea, <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samoa" title="Samoa">Samoa</a>, the Solomon Islands, <a href="/wiki/Tokelau" title="Tokelau">Tokelau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wallis_and_Futuna" title="Wallis and Futuna">Wallis and Futuna</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Minor_Outlying_Islands" title="United States Minor Outlying Islands">United States Minor Outlying Islands</a> (<a href="/wiki/Baker_Island" title="Baker Island">Baker Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Howland_Island" title="Howland Island">Howland Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jarvis_Island" title="Jarvis Island">Jarvis Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midway_Atoll" title="Midway Atoll">Midway Atoll</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palmyra_Atoll" title="Palmyra Atoll">Palmyra Atoll</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wake_Island" title="Wake Island">Wake Island</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-1"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> The island nations of <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, Japan and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, all located in the Pacific Ocean, are excluded from the UN definition. Further excluded are <a href="/wiki/East_Timor" title="East Timor">East Timor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_New_Guinea" title="Western New Guinea">Indonesian New Guinea/Western New Guinea</a>, areas which are biogeographically or geologically associated with the Australian landmass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a> also categorizes Oceania as one of the major continental divisions of the world, but the name "Australia and Oceania" is used. Their definition does not include all of Australia's external territories, but is otherwise the same as the UN's definition, and is also used for statistical purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> In a 2008 article titled <i>Oceania and Security: A Perspective from New Zealand</i>, author Peter Cozens stated, "the region of Oceania is characterised by vast distances
across the sea between continental land masses [...] It is difficult to be precise about the term Oceania and its exact delimitation", adding that "the principal regional political grouping is contained within the Pacific Island Forum (PIF) - the 16 states making up the Forum are: Australia, Cook Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Fiji, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Nauru, New Zealand, Niue, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu and Vanuatu - in general terms this is the area referred to as Oceania by the United Nations and similar agencies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The Pacific Islands Forum expanded during the early 2010s, and areas that were already included in the UN definition of Oceania, such as French Polynesia, gained membership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_interpretations">Early interpretations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Early interpretations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:412px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2814" data-file-width="5319" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg/410px-Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg/615px-Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg/820px-Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg 2x" width="410"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Meyers_b12_s0582a.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A German map of Oceania from 1884, showing the region to encompass Australia and all islands between Asia and <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>French writer <a href="/wiki/Gustave_d%27Eichthal" title="Gustave d'Eichthal">Gustave d'Eichthal</a> remarked in 1844 that, "the boundaries of Oceania are in reality those of the great ocean itself."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eic_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-eic-67">[67]</a></sup> In 1887, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Asiatic_Society_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain and Ireland">Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain and Ireland</a> referred to Australia as the area's westernmost land,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> while in 1870 British Revernard <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Murdoch_Mackay" title="Alexander Murdoch Mackay">Alexander Mackay</a> identified the Bonin Islands as its northernmost point, and Macquarie Island as its southernmost point.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mac_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-mac-69">[69]</a></sup> The Bonin Islands at that time were a possession of Britain; Macquarie Island, to the south of <a href="/wiki/Tasmania" title="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, is a subantarctic island in the Pacific. It was politically associated with Australia by 1870.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alfred Russel Wallace believed in 1879 that Oceania extended to the <a href="/wiki/Aleutian_Islands" title="Aleutian Islands">Aleutian Islands</a>, which are among the northernmost islands of the Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-austral_37-2"><a href="#cite_note-austral-37">[37]</a></sup> The islands, now politically associated with <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a>, have historically had <a href="/wiki/Aleut" title="Aleut">inhabitants</a> that were related to <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous peoples of the Americas">Indigenous Americans</a>, in addition to having non-tropical biogeography similar to that of Alaska and <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> Wallace insisted that while the surface area of this wide definition was greater than that of Asia and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> combined, the land area was only a little greater than that of Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-austral_37-3"><a href="#cite_note-austral-37">[37]</a></sup> American geographer Sophia S. Cornell claimed that the Aleutian Islands were not part of Oceania in 1857.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corn_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-corn-32">[32]</a></sup> She stated that Oceania was divided up into three groups; Australasia (which included Australia, New Zealand and the Melanesian islands), Malaysia (which included all present-day countries within the Malay Archipelago, not just the country of <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>) and Polynesia (which included both the Polynesian and Micronesian islands in her definition).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corn_32-2"><a href="#cite_note-corn-32">[32]</a></sup> Aside from mainland Australia, areas that she identified as of high importance were <a href="/wiki/Borneo" title="Borneo">Borneo</a>, Hawaiʻi, Indonesia's <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sumatra" title="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a>, New Zealand, the Philippines, French Polynesia's <a href="/wiki/Society_Islands" title="Society Islands">Society Islands</a>, Tasmania, and Tonga.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-corn_32-3"><a href="#cite_note-corn-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Publication <i>Missionary Review of the World</i> claimed in 1895 that Oceania was divided up into five groups; Australasia, Malaysia, Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia. It did not consider Hawaiʻi to be part of Polynesia, due to its geographic isolation, commenting that Oceania also included, "isolated groups and islands, such as the Hawaiʻian and <a href="/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_Islands" title="Galápagos Islands">Galápagos</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-missionary_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-missionary-33">[33]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rand_McNally" title="Rand McNally">Rand McNally &amp; Company</a>, an American publisher of maps and atlases, claimed in 1892 that, "Oceania comprises the large island of Australia and the innumerable islands of the Pacific Ocean" and also that the islands of the Malay Archipelago "should be grouped in with Asia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> British linguist <a href="/wiki/Robert_Needham_Cust" title="Robert Needham Cust">Robert Needham Cust</a> argued in 1887 that the Malay Archipelago should be excluded since it had participated in Asian civilization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ess_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-ess-74">[74]</a></sup> Cust considered Oceania's four subregions to be Australasia, Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ess_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-ess-74">[74]</a></sup> New Zealand were categorized by him as being in Polynesia; as such the only country in his definition of Australasia was Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ess_74-2"><a href="#cite_note-ess-74">[74]</a></sup> His definition of Polynesia included both Easter Island and Hawaiʻi, which had not yet been annexed by either Chile or the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ess_74-3"><a href="#cite_note-ess-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Journal_of_the_Royal_Statistical_Society" title="Journal of the Royal Statistical Society">Journal of the Royal Statistical Society</a></i> stated in 1892 that Australia was a large island within Oceania rather than a small continent. It additionally commented, "it is certainly not necessary to consider the Hawaiian Islands and Australia as being in the same part of the world, it is however permissible to unite in one group all the islands which are scattered over the great ocean. It should be remarked that if we take the Malay Archipelago away from Oceania, as do generally the German geographers, the insular world contained in the great ocean is cut in two, and the least populated of the five parts of the world is diminished in order to increase the number of inhabitants of the most densely populated continent."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> Regarding Australia and the Pacific, <i>Chambers's New Handy Volume American Encyclopædia</i> observed in 1885 that, "the whole region has sometimes been called Oceania, and sometimes Australasia—generally, however, in modern times, to the exclusion of the islands in the [Malay] Archipelago, to which certain writers have given the name of Malaysia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chambers_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-chambers-76">[76]</a></sup> It added there was controversy over the exact limits of Oceania, saying that, "scarcely any two geographers appear to be quite agreed upon the subject."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chambers_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-chambers-76">[76]</a></sup> The 1926 book <i>Modern World History, 1776-1926: A Survey of the Origins and Development of Contemporary Civilization</i>, by author Alexander Clarence Flick, considered Oceania to include all islands in the Pacific, and associated the term with the Aleutian Islands, the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a>, the Malay Archipelago, the <a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands">Ryukyu Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>, and Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flick_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-flick-77">[77]</a></sup> Flick estimated this all encompassing definition of Oceania had a population of 70,000,000, and commented that, "brown and yellow races constitute the vast majority" and that the minority of whites were mainly "owners and rulers."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flick_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-flick-77">[77]</a></sup> He added, "through trade relations, the work of <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">missionaries</a> and teachers, and political control, western civilization is slowly penetrating these out of the way places either directly, or indirectly through Europeanized powers like Japan."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flick_77-2"><a href="#cite_note-flick-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_and_contemporary_interpretations">Historical and contemporary interpretations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Historical and contemporary interpretations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In a 1972 article for the <i>Music Educators Journal</i> titled <i>Musics of Oceania</i>, author Raymond F. Kennedy wrote, "many meanings have been given to the word Oceania. The most inclusive–but not always the most useful–embraces about 25,000 land areas between Asia and the Americas. A more popular and practical definition excludes Indonesia, East Malaysia (Borneo), the Philippines, Formosa (Taiwan), Japan and other islands closely related to the Asian mainland, as well as the Aleutians."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Government_Publishing_Office" title="United States Government Publishing Office">U.S. Government Publishing Office</a>'s <i>Area Handbook for Oceania</i> from 1971 states that Australia and New Zealand are the principal large sovereignties of the area. It further states, "Oceania sometimes refers to the land areas of the south central Pacific. At other times it is considered to include all islands between Asia and <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>. Usually, however, the Ryukyu and Aleutian Islands, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_archipelago" title="Japanese archipelago">Japanese Archipelago</a>, are not thought of as being included. Ordinarily, also, Indonesia, the Philippines and Taiwan are regarded as a part of the Asian mainland."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handbook_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-handbook-79">[79]</a></sup> In 1948, American military journal <i>Armed Forces Talk</i> broke the islands of the Pacific up into five major subdivisions; Indonesia, Melanesia, Micronesia, Polynesia and the non-tropical Islands. The Indonesia subdivision consisted of the islands of the Malay Archipelago, while the non-tropical islands were categorized as being the Aleutian Islands, the Japanese Archipelago, <a href="/wiki/Kodiak_Archipelago" title="Kodiak Archipelago">Kodiak</a>, the Kuril Islands, Sakhalin and Taiwan, among others. It associated the term Oceania with the Melanesian, Micronesian and Polynesian subdivisions, but not with the Indonesian or non-tropical subdivisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the 1998 book <i>Encyclopedia of Earth and Physical Sciences</i>, Oceania includes Australia and more than 10,000 islands scattered across the Pacific Ocean. It notes, "some experts insist that Oceania encompasses even the cold Aleutian Islands and the islands of Japan. Disagreement also exists over whether or not Indonesia, the Philippines and Taiwan should be included in Oceania."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> Taiwan and the Japanese and Malay Archipelagos are often deemed as a geological extension of Asia, since they do not have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oceanic_islands" title="Oceanic islands">oceanic geology</a>, instead primarily being detached fragments of the Asian continent that were once physiologically connected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chen_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-chen-83">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Certain Japanese islands off the main archipelago do have oceanic geology, having formed through volcanic activity in the ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> The book <i>The World and Its Peoples: Australia, New Zealand, Oceania</i> (1966) asserts that, "Japan, Taiwan, the Aleutian Islands, Indonesia, the Philippines and Malaysia [and] the Pacific archipelagos bordering upon the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">Far East Asian</a> mainland are excluded from Oceania", and that "all the islands lying between Australia and the Americas, including Australia, are part of Oceania."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nz_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-nz-87">[87]</a></sup> Furthermore, the book adds that Hawaiʻi is still within Oceania, despite being politically integrated into the U.S., and that the Pacific Ocean "gives unity to the whole" since "all these varied lands emerge from or border upon the Pacific."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nz_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-nz-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1876 book <i>The Countries of the World: Volume 4</i>, by British scientist and explorer <a href="/wiki/Robert_Brown_(botanist,_born_1842)" title="Robert Brown (botanist, born 1842)">Robert Brown</a>, labelled the Malay Archipelago as "Northwestern Oceania", but Brown still noted that these islands belonged more to the Asian continent. They are now often referred to as <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a>, with Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines being founding members of the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN" title="ASEAN">ASEAN</a> regional organization for <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> in 1967.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> Brown also categorized Japan and Taiwan as being in the same region of the world as the islands of Oceania, and excluded them from <i>The Countries of the World: Volume 5</i>, which focused on Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-2"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> However, Brown did not explicitly associate Japan or Taiwan with the term Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-3"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> He divided Oceania into two subregions; Eastern Oceania, which included the islands of Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia, and Southwestern Oceania, which included Australia and New Zealand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-4"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> The Juan Fernández Islands, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_Islands" title="Galápagos Islands">Galápagos Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Revillagigedo_Islands" title="Revillagigedo Islands">Revillagigedo Islands</a> were identified as the easternmost areas of Oceania in the book. Brown wrote, "they lie nearest the American continent of all oceanic islands, and though rarely associated with Polynesia, and never appearing to have been inhabited by any aboriginal races, are, in many ways, remarkable and interesting."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-5"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> Brown went on to add, "the small islands lying off the continent, like the <a href="/wiki/Haida_Gwaii" title="Haida Gwaii">Queen Charlotte's</a> in the North Pacific, the <a href="/wiki/Farallon_Islands" title="Farallon Islands">Farallones</a> off <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Chincha_Islands" title="Chincha Islands">Chinchas</a> off <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a> are — to all intents and purposes, only detached bits of the adjoining shores. But in the case of the Galápagos, at least, this is different."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-6"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> He also claimed that they are "often cited as illustrating the peculiar relation of such islands to continents. Mr. <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Darwin</a> has, for instance, adducted them as an illustration of the fact that such islands are inhabited by plants and animals closely allied to those of the nearest mainland, without actually being the same."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countriesoftheworld_60-7"><a href="#cite_note-countriesoftheworld-60">[60]</a></sup> The Juan Fernández Islands and the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Desventuradas_Islands" title="Desventuradas Islands">Desventuradas Islands</a> are today seen as the easternmost extension of the Indo-West Pacific biogeographic region. The islands lie on the Nazca Plate with Easter Island and the Galápagos Islands, and have a significant south central Pacific component to their marine fauna.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marine_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-marine-88">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-east_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-east-89">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-class_54-1"><a href="#cite_note-class-54">[54]</a></sup> According to scientific journal <i><a href="/wiki/PLOS_One" title="PLOS One">PLOS One</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Humboldt_Current" title="Humboldt Current">Humboldt Current</a> helps create a biogeographic barrier between the marine fauna of these islands and South America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marine_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-marine-88">[88]</a></sup> Chile's government have occasionally considered them to be within Oceania along with Easter Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> Chile's government also categorize Easter Island, the Desventurdas Islands and the Juan Fernández Islands as being part of a region titled <a href="/wiki/Insular_Chile" title="Insular Chile">Insular Chile</a>. They further include in this region <a href="/wiki/Isla_Salas_y_G%C3%B3mez" title="Isla Salas y Gómez">Salas y Gómez</a>, a small uninhabited island which is roughly 400 kilometers to the east of Easter Island. <i>PLOS One</i> describe Insular Chile as having "cultural and ecological connections to the broader insular Pacific."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marine_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-marine-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="520" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg/340px-Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg/510px-Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg/680px-Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg.png 2x" width="340"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Members_of_Pacific_Island_Forum.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of member states for the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands_Forum" title="Pacific Islands Forum">Pacific Islands Forum</a> (prior to 2022), the member states are depicted in blue. The PIF is a governing organization for the Pacific, and all of its members are seen as being politically within Oceania. Territories ethnographically associated with Oceania, but not politically associated with Oceania, such as Easter Island, Hawaiʻi, and Western New Guinea, have considered gaining representation in the PIF. The Pacific island nations of Indonesia, Japan and the Philippines are dialogue partners, but none have full membership. East Timor also have observer status, despite being located entirely within the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1678" data-file-width="3067" decoding="async" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png/340px-Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png/510px-Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png/680px-Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png 2x" width="340"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Territorial_Waters_of_the_Pacific_Ocean.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a> map of the Pacific which includes areas not politically associated with Oceania, that may be considered geographically or geologically within Oceania.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature" title="International Union for Conservation of Nature">International Union for Conservation of Nature</a> stated in a 1986 report that they include Easter Island in their definition of Oceania "on the basis of its Polynesian and biogeographic affinities even though it is politically apart", further noting that other islands administered by <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin American</a> countries had been included in definitions of Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> In 1987, <i>The Journal of Australasian Cave Research</i> described Oceania as being "the region from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irian_Jaya" title="Irian Jaya">Irian Jaya</a> (Western New Guinea, a province of New Guinea) in the west to Galápagos Islands (Equador) and Easter Island (Chile) in the east."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> In a 1980 report on <a href="/wiki/Sexually_transmitted_infection" title="Sexually transmitted infection">venereal diseases</a> in the South Pacific, the <i>British Journal of Venereal Diseases</i> categorized the Desventuradas Islands, Easter Island, the Galápagos Islands and the Juan Fernández Islands as being in an eastern region of the South Pacific, along with areas such as Pitcairn Islands and French Polynesia, but noted that the Galápagos Islands were not a member of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Community" title="Pacific Community">South Pacific Commission</a>, like most other islands in the South Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> The South Pacific Commission was formed in 1947 and is currently known as the Pacific Community; its members include Australia and other Pacific Islands Forum members. The 2007 book <i>Asia in the Pacific Islands: Replacing the West</i>, by New Zealand Pacific scholar <a href="/wiki/Ron_Crocombe" title="Ron Crocombe">Ron Crocombe</a>, defined the term 'Pacific Islands' as being islands within the South Pacific Commission, and stated that such a definition "does not include Galápagos and other islands off the Pacific coast of the Americas; these were uninhabited when Europeans arrived, then integrated with a South American country and have almost no contact with other Pacific Islands." He adds, "Easter Island still participates in some Pacific Island affairs because its people are Polynesian."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asianpacific_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-asianpacific-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Thomas_Sebeok" title="Thomas Sebeok">Thomas Sebeok</a>'s two volume 1971 book <i>Linguistics in Oceania</i> defines Easter Island, the Galápagos Islands, the Juan Fernández Islands, <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">Costa Rica</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Cocos_Island" title="Cocos Island">Cocos Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Malpelo_Island" title="Malpelo Island">Malpelo Island</a> (all oceanic in origin) as making up a <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish language</a> segment of Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ling_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-ling-94">[94]</a></sup> Cocos Island and Malpelo Island are the only landmasses located on the <a href="/wiki/Cocos_Plate" title="Cocos Plate">Cocos Plate</a>, which is to the north of the Nazca Plate. The book observed that a native Polynesian language was still understood on Easter Island, unlike with the other islands, which were uninhabited when discovered by Europeans and mostly being used as prisons for convicts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ling_94-1"><a href="#cite_note-ling-94">[94]</a></sup> Additionally, the book includes Taiwan and the entire Malay Archipelago as part of Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lingtai_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-lingtai-95">[95]</a></sup> While not oceanic in nature, Taiwan and Malay Archipelago countries like Indonesia and the Philippines share <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesians" title="Austronesians">Austronesian</a> ethnolinguistic origins with Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia, hence their inclusion in the book.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lingtai_95-1"><a href="#cite_note-lingtai-95">[95]</a></sup> The book defined Oceania's major subregions as being Australia, Indonesia (which included all areas associated with the Malay Archipelago), Melanesia, Micronesia and Polynesia. It stated that Oceania was, "an area of perhaps a thousand indigenous languages, where a score of Asian mainland languages, half-a-dozen European languages, and a couple of <a href="/wiki/Pidgin" title="Pidgin">pidgins</a>, are commonly spoken", adding that "the opportunities for studying language contact and bilingualism at all levels and in all historical stages are unexcelled. It is to be hoped that linguists will grasp at the opportunities."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ling_94-2"><a href="#cite_note-ling-94">[94]</a></sup> In 2010, Australian historian Bronwen Douglas claimed in <i>The Journal of Pacific History</i> that "a strong case could be made for extending Oceania to at least Taiwan, the homeland of the Austronesian language family whose speakers colonized significant parts of the region about 6,000 years ago."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> For political reasons, Taiwan was a member of the <a href="/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation" title="Oceania Football Confederation">Oceania Football Confederation</a> during the 1970s and 1980s, rather than the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation" title="Asian Football Confederation">Asian Football Confederation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ian Todd's 1974 book <i>Island Realm: A Pacific Panorama</i> also defines oceanic islands administered by Latin American countries as making up a Spanish language segment of Oceania, while also defining the oceanic Bonin Islands as making up a <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese language</a> segment of Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-realm_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-realm-58">[58]</a></sup> Todd further includes the non-tropical Aleutian Islands in his definition of Oceania. The island chain borders both the Pacific Plate as well as the <a href="/wiki/North_American_Plate" title="North American Plate">North American Plate</a>, and is geologically a partially submerged western extension of the <a href="/wiki/Aleutian_Range" title="Aleutian Range">Aleutian Range</a> on the Alaskan mainland, that stretches for another 1,600 kilometers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB1911_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB1911-101">[101]</a></sup> <i>The Stockholm Journal of East Asian Studies</i> stated in 1996 that Oceania was defined as Australia and an ensemble of various Pacific Islands, "particularly those in the central and south Pacific [but] never those in the extreme north, for example the Aleutian chain."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> In the <i>Pacific Ocean Handbook</i> (1945), Eliot Grinnell Mears wrote "while there is no standard definition of Oceania, it is customary to exclude the Aleutians of the North Pacific." Mears said he included Australia and New Zealand in Oceania for "scientific reasons; Australia's fauna is largely continental in character, New Zealand's are clearly insular; and neither <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth realm</a> has close ties with Asia." He further added that, "the term 'Australasia' is not relished by <a href="/wiki/New_Zealanders" title="New Zealanders">New Zealanders</a> and this name is too often confused with 'Australia'."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pac_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-pac-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>American historian <a href="/wiki/James_Clifford_(historian)" title="James Clifford (historian)">James Clifford</a> argued for the inclusion of Alaskan islands in his 2013 book <i>Returns</i>, writing, "if <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea_Highlands" title="New Guinea Highlands">Highland New Guinea</a> can be part of Oceania, then why not Kodiak—its people having lived for so long with and from the ocean." He added that, "I recalled the Kodiak area's devastating 20th century volcanic eruptions and earthquakes along the <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>, geologically it's a very Pacific place, however far north"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clif_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-clif-104">[104]</a></sup> and that, "others have questioned how the Pacific or Oceania got reduced to the south Pacific (and well before <a href="/wiki/James_A._Michener" title="James A. Michener">James Michner</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Tales_of_the_South_Pacific" title="Tales of the South Pacific">Tales of the South Pacific</a></i>)."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clif_104-1"><a href="#cite_note-clif-104">[104]</a></sup> In 2014, American historian Ryan Tucker Jones wrote in <i>The Journal of Pacific History</i> that "several themes prominent in the history of Oceania – such as humans’ orientation towards the ocean, the complex ways in which European and Indigenous histories mixed in the colonial era, and the notion of vast, interconnected spaces – apply to North Pacific history as well", adding that "the history of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Russian Far East</a> and Alaska could be written as Pacific history and integrated into histories of Oceania. Such an integration would provide numerous benefits for historians and activists in the North Pacific."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> Murakami Hyôe's 1977 book <i>Guides to Japanese Culture</i> states, "I feel that I must go so far as to say that the culture of <a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands">Okinawa</a> and Japan is not <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental" title="Oriental">oriental</a> culture. Geographically, we are a part of Asia, but we do not have the same fate as the Asian continent, and should be considered a part of Pacific island culture."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> In 1961, Japanese novelist <a href="/wiki/Toshio_Shimao" title="Toshio Shimao">Toshio Shimao</a> coined the term "Japanesia", which refers to the idea of re-mapping
Japan as a Pacific archipelago rather than as an outlying region of Asia. He wrote in 1962 that, "our Japan is often considered in terms of its separation from continental Asia, but there is another way of seeing it. Together with Polynesia, Micronesia and Indonesia, it is also one of a number of island groups in the Pacific Ocean. When we become more conscious of this facet of our Japan, its Japanesian aspect will be
assured."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his 2015 book <i>Native Peoples of the World: An Encyclopedia of Groups, Cultures and Contemporary Issues</i>, American historian <a href="/wiki/Steven_L._Danver" title="Steven L. Danver">Steven L. Danver</a> claimed that, "the term Oceania, in its broadest sense, includes all insular regions between Asia and the Americas. While Japan and the Ryukyu Islands usually are considered part of Asia, and the Aleutians are viewed as a part of the Americas, in fact, these islands represent the northern part of Oceania. Likewise, the islands of the <a href="/wiki/East_Indies" title="East Indies">East Indies</a>, the Philippines, Taiwan (or Formosa), and Indonesia belong to Oceania, as does Australia. However, Oceania most commonly is understood to refer to the islands in the center of the Pacific Ocean."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> Alain Chenevière's 1995 book <i>Pacific: the Boundless Ocean</i> similarly states that, "In its restricted sense, Oceania includes all land masses in the Pacific." Unlike Danver, Chenevière does not consider the Aleutian Islands, Indonesia, Japan or the Philippines to form part of Oceania, due to their geological and historical links to other continents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chen_83-1"><a href="#cite_note-chen-83">[83]</a></sup> British historian <a href="/wiki/David_Armitage_(historian)" title="David Armitage (historian)">David Armitage</a> wrote in his 2014 book <i>Pacific Histories: Ocean, Land, People</i> that, "New Zealand and even Australia are sometimes considered part of the Pacific, sometimes not. Archipelagos which might otherwise appear to be 'in' the Pacific are by convention usually excluded: Indonesia (excluding <a href="/wiki/Western_New_Guinea" title="Western New Guinea">West Papua</a>), the Philippines, the Aleutians or even Japan. And yet Timor Leste (or East Timor) is an observer of the Pacific Islands Forum." Armitage adds that, "various geographers carve up this part of the world differently, using a range of labels such as Oceania, <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" title="Asia-Pacific">Asia-Pacific</a>, the Pacific-Basin, the South Pacific or South Seas (which commonly includes islands in the north) or the Pacific Islands. Of course, all the seas are connected, and there are no neat limits.
