But the struggle for putting the Pacific into discourse is partly decided by how it is defined."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arm_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-arm-109">[109]</a></sup> Australian historian Stuart Macintyre reflects in his 2009 book <i>A Concise History of Australia</i> that, "Australians commonly regard themselves, along with New Zealanders, as part of Oceania, and they have liked to think they enjoy a special relation with the most powerful of all <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English-speaking</a> countries on the other side of that ocean", however, he added that "as the balance of regional power shifted, Australians increasingly claim they are part of Asia and regard their earlier presence in the Pacific as a romantic interlude in tropical islands far removed from the business hub of <a href="/wiki/Four_Asian_Tigers" title="Four Asian Tigers">Asian tigers</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> The <i>Islands Business Pacific</i> journal stated in 1991 that, "the use of the term Oceania is changing. More and more Oceania is being accepted as referring to the islands of Polynesia, Melanesia and Micronesia and not to include Australia and New Zealand. Watching their limplingly unconfident drift towards the direction of ASEAN, one might even conclude that they are wallowing forlornly in limbo."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Surveys during the 2010s indicated that students from the island state of Tasmania mainly viewed Australia's area as the Pacific or Oceania, rather than Asia-Pacific, <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pacific" title="Indo-Pacific">Indo-Pacific</a> or Asia. The <i>History Australia</i> journal stated in 2018 that this was because "they perceive their region to be a set of neighboring islands in the South Pacific. The idea of Australia as an island continent – plus Tasmania, among other islands – appealed to this group. They perceived Australia as a close neighbor to many Pacific islands, including New Zealand [...] Consistent with the views of the previous years, mainland Asia lay beyond their horizons."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hist_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-hist-112">[112]</a></sup> In a 2021 poll by Australian <a href="/wiki/Think_tank" title="Think tank">think tank</a> the <a href="/wiki/Lowy_Institute" title="Lowy Institute">Lowy Institute</a>, the majority of respondents (62%) chose Australia as being part of Oceania. 38% selected the Indo-Pacific; 32% selected <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">the West</a> and 21% selected Asia. 11% also selected Australia as 'not part of anywhere'".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>American <a href="/wiki/Herpetology" title="Herpetology">herpetologist</a> <a class="extiw" href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Robert_Zug" title="de:George Robert Zug">George R. Zug</a> has written that his preferred definition of Oceania emphasis islands with oceanic geology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zug_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-zug-114">[114]</a></sup> In his 2013 book <i>Reptiles and Amphibians of the Pacific Islands</i>, Zug stated that oceanic islands are, "islands with no past connections to a continental landmass" and that, "these boundaries encompass the Hawaiian and Bonin Islands in the north and Easter Island in the south, and the <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> Islands in the west to the Galápagos Islands in the east."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zug_114-1"><a href="#cite_note-zug-114">[114]</a></sup> Unlike the United Nations, the World Factbook defines the still-uninhabited Clipperton Island as being a discrete political entity, and they categorize it as part of North America, presumably due to its relative proximity (situated 1,200 kilometers off Mexico on the Pacific Plate). Clipperton is not politically associated with the Americas, as is the case with other oceanic islands nearing the Americas, having had almost no interaction with the continent throughout its history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> From the early 20th century to 2007, the island was administratively part of French Polynesia, which itself was known as French Oceania up until 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In terms of marine fauna, Clipperton shares similarities with areas of the Pacific which are much farther removed from the Americas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clipzoo_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-clipzoo-119">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Scottish author <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hope_Moncrieff" title="Robert Hope Moncrieff">Robert Hope Moncrieff</a> considered Clipperton to be the easternmost point of Oceania in 1907,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/GlobalSecurity.org" title="GlobalSecurity.org">GlobalSecurity.org</a> also include it in their definition, along with the Bonin Islands, Easter Island, the Galápagos Islands and Hawaiʻi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-global_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-global-122">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other uninhabited Pacific Ocean landmasses have been explicitly associated with Oceania,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-janick_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-janick-123">[123]</a></sup> including the highly remote Baker Island and Wake Island (now administered by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">U.S. military</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-2"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-global_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-global-122">[122]</a></sup> This is due to their location in the center of the Pacific, their biogeography and their oceanic geology. Less isolated oceanic islands that were once uninhabited, such as the Bonin Islands and Juan Fernández Islands, have since been sparsely populated by citizens of their political administrators.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-realm_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-realm-58">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ling_94-3"><a href="#cite_note-ling-94">[94]</a></sup> Archaeological evidence suggests that <a href="/wiki/Micronesians" title="Micronesians">Micronesians</a> may have lived on the Bonin Islands <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 2,000 years ago, but they were uninhabited at the time of European discovery in the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Like with these historically uninhabited areas, Australia, Hawaiʻi, New Zealand, and Western New Guinea have also had diverging developments since European discovery, and they are still intertwined to the region not just through their geographical location or geology, but through past and present indigenous populations as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-devchris_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-devchris-125">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-asianpacific_19-2"><a href="#cite_note-asianpacific-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-francepacific_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-francepacific-126">[126]</a></sup> The <i>East Asia</i> journal observes that, "Australia is often described as a 'big brother' to island countries: part of the Pacific family by geography and history but set apart by wealth and national identity. With its Polynesian heritage, New Zealand has a greater claim to cultural connection with the Pacific. Australia and New Zealand are close allies, and consult closely on their engagement with Pacific island states. For the most part, they pursue a shared approach."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Australians" title="Indigenous Australians">Indigenous Australians</a> are not considered to be Austronesians, although in 1940 Australian anthropologist <a href="/wiki/Fred_McCarthy_(archaeologist)" title="Fred McCarthy (archaeologist)">Fred McCarthy</a> described their culture as being "indissolubly bound up with that of Oceania."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> On the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Census" title="United States Census">United States Census</a>, they are categorized under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander_American" title="Pacific Islander American">Pacific Islander American</a> umbrella with Melanesians, Micronesians and Polynesians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Umich_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Umich-130">[130]</a></sup> Some theorize that Indigenous Australians are related to the Ainu people, who are the original inhabitants of Japan's <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>'s Sakhalin and Kuril Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_people" title="Ryukyuan people">indigenous inhabitants</a> of Japan's Ryukyu Islands are also theorized to be related to Austronesians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Boundaries_between_subregions">Boundaries between subregions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Boundaries between subregions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Depending on the definition, New Zealand could be part of Polynesia, or part of Australasia with Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> New Zealand was originally settled by the Polynesian <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people" title="Māori people">Māoris</a>, and has long maintained a political influence over the subregion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-southsea_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-southsea-135">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lowy18_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-lowy18-136">[136]</a></sup> Through immigration and high Māori birth rates, New Zealand has attained the largest population of Polynesians in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> while Australia has the third largest Polynesian population (consisting entirely of immigrants). Modern-day Indigenous Australians are loosely related to Melanesians,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> and Australia maintains political influence over Melanesia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lowy18_136-1"><a href="#cite_note-lowy18-136">[136]</a></sup> which is mostly located on the same tectonic plate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birds_52-4"><a href="#cite_note-birds-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plates_53-4"><a href="#cite_note-plates-53">[53]</a></sup> Despite this, Australia is rarely seen as a part of the subregion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Codrington_Melanesians_Encyc_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Codrington_Melanesians_Encyc-141">[141]</a></sup> As with Australia and New Zealand, Melanesia's New Caledonia has a significant non-indigenous European population, numbering around 71,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-142">[142]</a></sup> Conversely, New Caledonia has still had a similar history to the rest of Melanesia, and their <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>-speaking Europeans make up only 27% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-142">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-devchris_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-devchris-125">[125]</a></sup> As such, it is not also culturally considered a part of the predominantly English-speaking Australasia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emb_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-emb-143">[143]</a></sup> Some cultural and political definitions of Australasia include most or all of Melanesia, due to its geographical proximity to Australia and New Zealand, but these are rare.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZOD_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-NZOD-144">[144]</a></sup> Australia, New Zealand and the islands of Melanesia are more commonly grouped together as part of the <a href="/wiki/Australasian_realm" title="Australasian realm">Australasian biogeographical realm</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> The UN's name for the Australasia subregion is "Australia and New Zealand"; their definition includes New Zealand, but places Papua New Guinea in Melanesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-3"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> Papua New Guinea is geographically the closest country to Australia, and is often geologically associated with Australia as it was once physiologically connected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-4"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> The UN's definition of this subregion also includes Australia's Indian Ocean <a href="/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia" title="States and territories of Australia">external territories</a> of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-5"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> They lie within the bounds of the Australian Plate and are sometimes geographically associated with Southeast Asia due to their proximity to western Indonesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Both were uninhabited when discovered by Europeans during the 17th century. Approximately half of the population on these islands are <a href="/wiki/European_Australians" title="European Australians">European Australian</a> mainlanders (with smaller numbers being <a href="/wiki/European_New_Zealanders" title="European New Zealanders">European New Zealanders</a>), while the other half are immigrants from <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> or the nearby Malay Archipelago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Census2016_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-Census2016-151">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> The UN further define the subregion as including Australia's Indian Ocean external territory Heard Island and McDonald Islands. These islands lie on the <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Plate" title="Antarctic Plate">Antarctic Plate</a> and are also thought of as being in Antarctica or no region at all, due to their extreme geographical isolation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-geo_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-geo-153">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-6"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> The World Factbook define Heard Island and McDonald Islands as part of Antarctica, while placing Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands as the westernmost extent of Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Norfolk_Island" title="Norfolk Island">Norfolk Island</a>, an external territory of Australia, was inhabited in prehistoric times by either Melanesians or Polynesians, and is geographically adjacent to the islands of Melanesia. The current inhabitants are mostly European Australians, and the UN categorize it as being in the Australasia subregion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stats_61-7"><a href="#cite_note-stats-61">[61]</a></sup> The 1982 edition of the <i>South Pacific Handbook</i>, by David Stanley, groups Australia, New Zealand, Norfolk Island, and Hawaiʻi together under an "Anglonesia" category. This is in spite of the geographical distance separating these areas from Hawaiʻi, which technically lies in the North Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> The 1985 edition of the <i>South Pacific Handbook</i> also groups the Galápagos Islands as being in Polynesia, while noting that they are not culturally a part of the subregion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> The islands are typically grouped with others in the southeastern Pacific that were never inhabited by Polynesians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-veg_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-veg-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Bonin Islands are in the same biogeographical realm as the geographically adjacent Micronesia, and are often grouped in with the subregion because of this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-veg_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-veg-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian peoples</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Oceania" title="History of Oceania">History of Oceania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Pacific_Islands" title="History of the Pacific Islands">History of the Pacific Islands</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia">Australia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Australia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Australia" title="Prehistory of Australia">Prehistory of Australia</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Indigenous_Australians" title="History of Indigenous Australians">History of Indigenous Australians</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout,_from_Australia_(1876,_vol_II).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1363" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout%2C_from_Australia_%281876%2C_vol_II%29.jpg/260px-Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout%2C_from_Australia_%281876%2C_vol_II%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout%2C_from_Australia_%281876%2C_vol_II%29.jpg/390px-Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout%2C_from_Australia_%281876%2C_vol_II%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout%2C_from_Australia_%281876%2C_vol_II%29.jpg/520px-Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout%2C_from_Australia_%281876%2C_vol_II%29.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Native_Encampment_by_Skinner_Prout,_from_Australia_(1876,_vol_II).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A 19th-century engraving of an Aboriginal Australian encampment</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Australians" title="Indigenous Australians">Indigenous Australians</a> are the original inhabitants of the Australian continent and nearby islands who migrated from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> to <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 70,000 years ago<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scimag_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-scimag-161">[161]</a></sup> and arrived in Australia <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 50,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-illumina.com_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-illumina.com-162">[162]</a></sup> They are believed to be among the <a href="/wiki/Recent_African_origin_of_modern_humans" title="Recent African origin of modern humans">earliest human migrations out of Africa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBSRC_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBSRC-163">[163]</a></sup> Although they likely migrated to Australia through Southeast Asia they are not demonstrably related to any known Asian or Polynesian population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ourcount_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-ourcount-164">[164]</a></sup> There is evidence of genetic and linguistic interchange between Australians in the far north and the Austronesian peoples of modern-day <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a> and the islands, but this may be the result of recent trade and <a href="/wiki/Interracial_marriage" title="Interracial marriage">intermarriage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-germs314_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-germs314-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>They reached <a href="/wiki/Tasmania" title="Tasmania">Tasmania</a> <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 40,000 years ago by migrating across a <a href="/wiki/Land_bridge" title="Land bridge">land bridge</a> from the mainland that existed during the last <a href="/wiki/Ice_age" title="Ice age">ice age</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prehis_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-prehis-166">[166]</a></sup> It is believed that the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_human_migration" title="Early human migration">early human migration</a> to Australia was achieved when this landmass formed part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sahul_continent" title="Sahul continent">Sahul continent</a>, connected to the island of New Guinea via a land bridge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-perspe81_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-perspe81-167">[167]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Torres_Strait_Islanders" title="Torres Strait Islanders">Torres Strait Islanders</a> are indigenous to the <a href="/wiki/Torres_Strait" title="Torres Strait">Torres Strait</a> Islands, which are at the northernmost tip of <a href="/wiki/Queensland" title="Queensland">Queensland</a> near <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uow2004_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-uow2004-168">[168]</a></sup> The earliest definite human remains found in Australia are that of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mungo_Man" title="Mungo Man">Mungo Man</a>, which have been dated at <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 40,000 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pmid4570638_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-pmid4570638-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Melanesia">Melanesia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Melanesia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_New_Guinea" title="History of New Guinea">History of New Guinea</a></div>
<p>The original inhabitants of the group of islands now named Melanesia were likely the ancestors of the present-day <a href="/wiki/Papuan_languages" title="Papuan languages">Papuan</a>-speaking people. Migrating from South-East Asia, they appear to have occupied these islands as far east as the main islands in the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands_(archipelago)" title="Solomon Islands (archipelago)">Solomon Islands archipelago</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Makira" title="Makira">Makira</a> and possibly the smaller islands farther to the east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-struct2072_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-struct2072-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>Particularly along the north coast of New Guinea and in the islands north and east of New Guinea, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesian_people" title="Austronesian people">Austronesian people</a>, who had migrated into the area somewhat more than 3,000 years ago, came into contact with these pre-existing populations of Papuan-speaking peoples. In the late 20th century, some scholars theorized a long period of interaction, which resulted in many complex changes in genetics, languages, and culture among the peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-malenes_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-malenes-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Micronesia">Micronesia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Micronesia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Federated_States_of_Micronesia" title="History of the Federated States of Micronesia">History of the Federated States of Micronesia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2191" data-file-width="2898" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg/220px-HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg/330px-HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg/440px-HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HH1883_pg125_Hafen_von_Jap.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stone money transport to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yap_Island" title="Yap Island">Yap Island</a> in Micronesia (1880)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="425" data-file-width="1053" decoding="async" height="89" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg/220px-Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg/330px-Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg/440px-Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chronological_dispersal_of_Austronesian_people_across_the_Pacific.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chronological dispersal of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesian_people" title="Austronesian people">Austronesian people</a> across the Pacific (per Bellwood in Chambers, 2008)</div></div></div>
<p>Micronesia began to be settled several millennia ago, although there are competing theories about the origin and arrival of the first settlers. There are numerous difficulties with conducting archaeological excavations in the islands, due to their size, settlement patterns and storm damage. As a result, much evidence is based on linguistic analysis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lapita_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-lapita-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest archaeological traces of civilization have been found on the island of <a href="/wiki/Saipan" title="Saipan">Saipan</a>, dated to 1500 BCE or slightly before. The ancestors of the <a href="/wiki/Micronesians" title="Micronesians">Micronesians</a> settled there over 4,000 years ago. A decentralized chieftain-based system eventually evolved into a more centralized economic and religious culture centered on <a href="/wiki/Yap" title="Yap">Yap</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pohnpei" title="Pohnpei">Pohnpei</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USDOS_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-USDOS-173">[173]</a></sup> The prehistories of many Micronesian islands such as Yap are not known very well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first people of the Northern Mariana Islands navigated to the islands and discovered it at some period between 4000 BCE to 2000 BCE from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South-East_Asia" title="South-East Asia">South-East Asia</a>. They became known as the <a href="/wiki/Chamorro_people" title="Chamorro people">Chamorros</a>. Their <a href="/wiki/Chamorro_language" title="Chamorro language">language</a> was named after them. The ancient Chamorro left a number of megalithic ruins, including <a href="/wiki/Latte_stone" title="Latte stone">Latte stone</a>. The Refaluwasch or <a href="/wiki/Carolinian_people" title="Carolinian people">Carolinian people</a> came to the Marianas in the 1800s from the <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Islands" title="Caroline Islands">Caroline Islands</a>. Micronesian colonists gradually settled the Marshall Islands during the <a href="/wiki/2nd_millennium_BC" title="2nd millennium BC">2nd millennium BC</a>E, with inter-island navigation made possible using <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands_stick_chart" title="Marshall Islands stick chart">traditional stick charts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-races165_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-races165-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Polynesia">Polynesia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Polynesia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hawaii" title="History of Hawaii">History of Hawaii</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_Zealand" title="History of New Zealand">History of New Zealand</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Discovery_and_settlement_of_Hawaii" title="Discovery and settlement of Hawaii">Discovery and settlement of Hawaii</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_navigation" title="Polynesian navigation">Polynesian navigation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AhuTongariki.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1026" data-file-width="1496" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/AhuTongariki.jpg/220px-AhuTongariki.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/AhuTongariki.jpg/330px-AhuTongariki.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/AhuTongariki.jpg/440px-AhuTongariki.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AhuTongariki.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Moai" title="Moai">Moai</a> at Ahu Tongariki on <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Rapa Nui (Easter Island)</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Polynesian people are considered to be by linguistic, archaeological and human genetic ancestry a subset of the sea-migrating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesian_people" title="Austronesian people">Austronesian people</a> and tracing <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_languages" title="Polynesian languages">Polynesian languages</a> places their <a href="/wiki/Prehistory" title="Prehistory">prehistoric</a> origins in the <a href="/wiki/Malay_Archipelago" title="Malay Archipelago">Malay Archipelago</a>, and ultimately, in <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Taiwan" title="Geography of Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. Between <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 3000 and 1000 BCE, speakers of <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a> began spreading from Taiwan into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Island_Southeast_Asia" title="Island Southeast Asia">Island South-East Asia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-matrilineality2003_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-matrilineality2003-176">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kayser,_M._2006_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kayser,_M._2006-177">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-polyori8225_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-polyori8225-178">[178]</a></sup> as tribes whose <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanese_aborigines" title="Taiwanese aborigines">natives</a> were thought to have arrived through South China <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 8,000 years ago to the edges of western Micronesia and on into Melanesia.
</p><p>In the archaeological record there are well-defined traces of this expansion which allow the path it took to be followed and dated with some certainty. It is thought that by roughly 1400 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wings_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-wings-179">[179]</a></sup> "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lapita" title="Lapita">Lapita</a> Peoples", so-named after their pottery tradition, appeared in the <a href="/wiki/Bismarck_Archipelago" title="Bismarck Archipelago">Bismarck Archipelago</a> of north-west Melanesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-test_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-test-180">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-burley128_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-burley128-181">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>Easter Islanders claimed that a chief <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hotu_Matu%27a" title="Hotu Matu'a">Hotu Matu'a</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vikings228_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-vikings228-182">[182]</a></sup> discovered the island in one or two large canoes with his wife and extended family.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hawaii_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-hawaii-183">[183]</a></sup> They are believed to have been <a href="/wiki/Polynesians" title="Polynesians">Polynesian</a>. Around 1200, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tahitian_people" title="Tahitian people">Tahitian</a> explorers discovered and began settling the area. This date range is based on <a href="/wiki/Glottochronology" title="Glottochronology">glottochronological</a> calculations and on three <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dates</a> from charcoal that appears to have been produced during forest clearance activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-failor89_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-failor89-184">[184]</a></sup> Moreover, a recent study which included radiocarbon dates from what is thought to be very early material suggests that the island was discovered and settled as recently as 1200.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scimag23874_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-scimag23874-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_exploration">European exploration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: European exploration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magellan%27s_circumnavigation" title="Magellan's circumnavigation">Magellan's circumnavigation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Australia_(1788%E2%80%931850)" title="History of Australia (1788–1850)">History of Australia (1788–1850)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_New_Zealand" title="Colony of New Zealand">Colony of New Zealand</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2210" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg/220px-1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg/330px-1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg/440px-1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1852_Bocage_Map_of_Australia_and_Polynesia_-_Geographicus_-_Oceanie-bocage-1852.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1852 map of Oceania by J. G. Barbié du Bocage. Includes regions of Polynesia, Micronesia, Melanesia, and <a href="/wiki/Malesia" title="Malesia">Malesia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Oceania was first explored by Europeans from the 16th century onwards. Portuguese navigators, between 1512 and 1526, reached the <a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Maluku Islands</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Abreu" title="António de Abreu">António de Abreu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Serr%C3%A3o" title="Francisco Serrão">Francisco Serrão</a> in 1512), <a href="/wiki/Timor" title="Timor">Timor</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Aru_Islands_Regency" title="Aru Islands Regency">Aru Islands</a> (Martim A. Melo Coutinho), the <a href="/wiki/Tanimbar_Islands" title="Tanimbar Islands">Tanimbar Islands</a>, some of the <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Islands" title="Caroline Islands">Caroline Islands</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Gomes_de_Sequeira" title="Gomes de Sequeira">Gomes de Sequeira</a> in 1525), and west <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Jorge_de_Menezes" title="Jorge de Menezes">Jorge de Menezes</a> in 1526). In 1519, a <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> expedition led by <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan" title="Ferdinand Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> sailed down the east coast of South America, found and sailed through the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Magellan" title="Strait of Magellan">strait that bears his name</a> and on 28 November 1520 entered the ocean which he named "Pacific". The three remaining ships, led by Magellan and his captains <a href="/wiki/Duarte_Barbosa" title="Duarte Barbosa">Duarte Barbosa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Serr%C3%A3o" title="João Serrão">João Serrão</a>, then sailed north and caught the <a href="/wiki/Trade_winds" title="Trade winds">trade winds</a> which carried them across the Pacific to the Philippines where Magellan was killed. One surviving ship led by <a href="/wiki/Juan_Sebasti%C3%A1n_Elcano" title="Juan Sebastián Elcano">Juan Sebastián Elcano</a> returned west across the Indian Ocean and <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_(ship)" title="Trinidad (ship)">the other</a> went north in the hope of finding the <a href="/wiki/Westerlies" title="Westerlies">westerlies</a> and reaching Mexico. Unable to find the right winds, it was forced to return to the East Indies. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Magellan%27s_circumnavigation" title="Timeline of Magellan's circumnavigation">Magellan-Elcano</a> expedition achieved the first <a href="/wiki/Circumnavigation" title="Circumnavigation">circumnavigation</a> of the world and reached the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Islands" title="Mariana Islands">Mariana Islands</a> and other islands of Oceania.
</p><p>From 1527 to 1595 a number of other large Spanish expeditions crossed the Pacific Ocean, leading to the arrival in <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands" title="Marshall Islands">Marshall Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a> in the North Pacific, as well as <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Marquesas_Islands" title="Marquesas Islands">Marquesas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands_(archipelago)" title="Solomon Islands (archipelago)">Solomon Islands archipelago</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Admiralty_Islands" title="Admiralty Islands">Admiralty Islands</a> in the South Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fernandez-Armesto_2006_305–307_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fernandez-Armesto_2006_305–307-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the quest for <a href="/wiki/Terra_Australis" title="Terra Australis">Terra Australis</a>, Spanish explorations in the 17th century, such as the expedition led by the Portuguese navigator <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Fernandes_de_Queir%C3%B3s" title="Pedro Fernandes de Queirós">Pedro Fernandes de Queirós</a>, sailed to <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a> archipelagos, and sailed the <a href="/wiki/Torres_Strait" title="Torres Strait">Torres Strait</a> between Australia and New Guinea, named after navigator <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_Vaz_de_Torres" title="Luís Vaz de Torres">Luís Vaz de Torres</a>. <a href="/wiki/Willem_Janszoon" title="Willem Janszoon">Willem Janszoon</a>, made the first completely documented European landing in Australia (1606), in <a href="/wiki/Cape_York_Peninsula" title="Cape York Peninsula">Cape York Peninsula</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-discos19_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-discos19-187">[187]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Abel_Tasman" title="Abel Tasman">Abel Janszoon Tasman</a> circumnavigated and landed on parts of the Australian continental coast and discovered <a href="/wiki/Van_Diemen%27s_Land" title="Van Diemen's Land">Van Diemen's Land</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Tasmania" title="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>), New Zealand in 1642, and <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-primary_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-primary-188">[188]</a></sup> He was the first known European explorer to reach these islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tearag_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-tearag-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 23 April 1770 British explorer <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">James Cook</a> made his first recorded direct observation of <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Australians" title="Indigenous Australians">indigenous Australians</a> at <a href="/wiki/Brush_Island" title="Brush Island">Brush Island</a> near <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bawley_Point,_New_South_Wales" title="Bawley Point, New South Wales">Bawley Point</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cook22470_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-cook22470-190">[190]</a></sup> On 29 April, Cook and crew made their first landfall on the mainland of the continent at a place now known as the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Silver_Beach_(Kurnell)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Silver Beach (Kurnell) (page does not exist)">Kurnell Peninsula</a>. It is here that James Cook made first contact with an aboriginal tribe known as the <a href="/wiki/Gweagal" title="Gweagal">Gweagal</a>. His expedition became the first recorded Europeans to have encountered its eastern coastline of Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herald86292_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-herald86292-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="European_settlement_and_colonisation">European settlement and colonisation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: European settlement and colonisation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Australia_(1788%E2%80%931850)" title="History of Australia (1788–1850)">History of Australia (1788–1850)</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_Zealand" title="History of New Zealand">History of New Zealand</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Guinea_(1884-1919).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="319" data-file-width="618" decoding="async" height="114" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/New_Guinea_%281884-1919%29.png/220px-New_Guinea_%281884-1919%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/New_Guinea_%281884-1919%29.png/330px-New_Guinea_%281884-1919%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/New_Guinea_%281884-1919%29.png/440px-New_Guinea_%281884-1919%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_Guinea_(1884-1919).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>New Guinea from 1884 to 1919. The Netherlands controlled the western half of New Guinea, <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a> the north-eastern part, and Britain the south-eastern part.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1789 the <a href="/wiki/Mutiny_on_the_Bounty" title="Mutiny on the Bounty">Mutiny on the Bounty</a> against <a href="/wiki/William_Bligh" title="William Bligh">William Bligh</a> led to several of the mutineers escaping the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> and settling on <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a>, which later became a British colony. Britain also established colonies in Australia in 1788, New Zealand in 1840 and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colonial_Fiji" title="Colonial Fiji">Fiji</a> in 1872, with much of Oceania becoming part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_Islands" title="Gilbert Islands">Gilbert Islands</a> (now known as <a href="/wiki/Kiribati" title="Kiribati">Kiribati</a>) and the Ellice Islands (now known as <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>) came under Britain's sphere of influence in the late 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TAHNPT_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-TAHNPT-192">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cinderella1_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-cinderella1-193">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>French Catholic missionaries arrived on Tahiti in 1834; their expulsion in 1836 caused France to send a gunboat in 1838. In 1842, Tahiti and <a href="/wiki/Tahuata" title="Tahuata">Tahuata</a> were declared a <a href="/wiki/Protectorate" title="Protectorate">French protectorate</a>, to allow Catholic missionaries to work undisturbed. The capital of <a href="/wiki/Papeete" title="Papeete">Papeetē</a> was founded in 1843.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KMLA1889_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-KMLA1889-194">[194]</a></sup> On 24 September 1853, under orders from <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_III" title="Napoleon III">Napoleon III</a>, Admiral <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Febvrier_Despointes" title="Auguste Febvrier Despointes">Febvrier Despointes</a> took formal possession of New Caledonia and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port-de-France" title="Port-de-France">Port-de-France</a> (Nouméa) was founded 25 June 1854.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ped_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-ped-195">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Spanish explorer <a href="/wiki/Alonso_de_Salazar" title="Alonso de Salazar">Alonso de Salazar</a> landed in the Marshall Islands in 1529. They were named by <a href="/wiki/Adam_Johann_von_Krusenstern" title="Adam Johann von Krusenstern">Krusenstern</a>, after English <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Explorer" title="Explorer">explorer</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Marshall_(British_captain)" title="John Marshall (British captain)">John Marshall</a>, who visited them together with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thomas_Gilbert_(captain)" title="Thomas Gilbert (captain)">Thomas Gilbert</a> in 1788, en route from <a href="/wiki/Botany_Bay" title="Botany Bay">Botany Bay</a> to <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Canton</a> (two ships of the <a href="/wiki/First_Fleet" title="First Fleet">First Fleet</a>). In 1905 the British government transferred some administrative responsibility over south-east New Guinea to Australia (which renamed the area "<a href="/wiki/Territory_of_Papua" title="Territory of Papua">Territory of Papua</a>"); and in 1906, transferred all remaining responsibility to Australia. The Marshall Islands were claimed by Spain in 1874. Germany established colonies in New Guinea in 1884, and <a href="/wiki/German_Samoa" title="German Samoa">Samoa</a> in 1900. The United States also expanded into the Pacific, beginning with <a href="/wiki/Baker_Island" title="Baker Island">Baker Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Howland_Island" title="Howland Island">Howland Island</a> in 1857, and with Hawaiʻi becoming a <a href="/wiki/Territory_of_Hawaii" title="Territory of Hawaii">U.S. territory</a> in 1898. Disagreements between the US, Germany and UK over Samoa led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tripartite_Convention_(1899)" title="Tripartite Convention (1899)">Tripartite Convention of 1899</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-amesagrey_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-amesagrey-196">[196]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Modern history">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">Pacific War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Oceania" title="Military history of Oceania">Military history of Oceania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_New_Zealand" title="Military history of New Zealand">Military history of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Australia_during_World_War_I" title="Military history of Australia during World War I">Military history of Australia during World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Australia_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of Australia during World War II">Military history of Australia during World War II</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Guam" title="History of Guam">History of Guam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Australia_(1901%E2%80%931945)" title="History of Australia (1901–1945)">History of Australia (1901–1945)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NZ_3rd_Division_(USMC_photo).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="484" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/NZ_3rd_Division_%28USMC_photo%29.jpg/220px-NZ_3rd_Division_%28USMC_photo%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/NZ_3rd_Division_%28USMC_photo%29.jpg/330px-NZ_3rd_Division_%28USMC_photo%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/NZ_3rd_Division_%28USMC_photo%29.jpg/440px-NZ_3rd_Division_%28USMC_photo%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NZ_3rd_Division_(USMC_photo).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>New Zealand troops land on <a href="/wiki/Vella_Lavella" title="Vella Lavella">Vella Lavella</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>One of the first land offensives in Oceania was the <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_German_Samoa" title="Occupation of German Samoa">Occupation of German Samoa</a> in August 1914 by <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Defence_Force" title="New Zealand Defence Force">New Zealand forces</a>. The campaign to take Samoa ended without bloodshed after over 1,000 New Zealanders landed on the German colony. Australian forces attacked <a href="/wiki/German_New_Guinea" title="German New Guinea">German New Guinea</a> in September 1914. A company of Australians and a British warship besieged the Germans and their colonial subjects, ending with a German surrender.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-awm.gov.au_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-awm.gov.au-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a> by the Japanese <a href="/wiki/Imperial_General_Headquarters" title="Imperial General Headquarters">Imperial General Headquarters</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearl17ff_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-pearl17ff-198">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-operat1315_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-operat1315-199">[199]</a></sup> was a surprise <a href="/wiki/Military_strike" title="Military strike">military strike</a> conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy" title="Imperial Japanese Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> against the United States <a href="/wiki/Naval_base" title="Naval base">naval base</a> at <a href="/wiki/Pearl_Harbor" title="Pearl Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaiʻi</a>, on the morning of 7 December 1941. The attack led to the <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of the United States during World War II">United States' entry into World War II</a>. The Japanese subsequently invaded New Guinea, Solomon Islands and other Pacific islands. The Japanese were turned back at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea" title="Battle of the Coral Sea">Battle of the Coral Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kokoda_Track_campaign" title="Kokoda Track campaign">Kokoda Track campaign</a> before they were finally defeated in 1945. Some of the most prominent Oceanic battlegrounds were the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bita_Paka" title="Battle of Bita Paka">Battle of Bita Paka</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands_campaign" title="Solomon Islands campaign">Solomon Islands campaign</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Darwin" title="Bombing of Darwin">Air raids on Darwin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kokoda_Track_campaign" title="Kokoda Track campaign">Kokada Track</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Borneo_campaign" title="Borneo campaign">Borneo campaign</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-decode32_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-decode32-200">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reconcil7_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-reconcil7-201">[201]</a></sup> The United States fought the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Guam_(1944)" title="Battle of Guam (1944)">Battle of Guam</a> from 21 July to 10 August 1944, to recapture the island from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_military" title="Japanese military">Japanese military</a> occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt1997_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt1997-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>Australia and New Zealand became <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Dominions" title="British Dominions">dominions</a> in the 20th century, adopting the <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931" title="Statute of Westminster 1931">Statute of Westminster Act</a> in 1942 and 1947 respectively. In 1946, Polynesians were granted French citizenship and the islands' status was changed to an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Overseas_administrative_territorial_entity" title="Overseas administrative territorial entity">overseas territory</a>; the islands' name was changed in 1957 to <i>Polynésie Française</i> (<a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>). Hawaiʻi became a <a href="/wiki/U.S._state" title="U.S. state">U.S. state</a> in 1959. <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a> became independent in 1970. On 1 May 1979, in recognition of the evolving political status of the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands" title="Marshall Islands">Marshall Islands</a>, the United States recognized the constitution of the Marshall Islands and the establishment of the Government of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_the_Marshall_Islands" title="Republic of the Marshall Islands">Republic of the Marshall Islands</a>. The South Pacific Forum was founded in 1971, which became the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands_Forum" title="Pacific Islands Forum">Pacific Islands Forum</a> in 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-awm.gov.au_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-awm.gov.au-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Territories_and_regions"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Oceanian_countries_by_population" title="List of Oceanian countries by population">List of Oceanian countries by population</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_in_Oceania" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Oceania">List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Oceania</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2816" data-file-width="2112" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG/170px-Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG/255px-Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG/340px-Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aoraki_Mount_Cook.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook" title="Aoraki / Mount Cook">Aoraki / Mount Cook</a>, located on the <a href="/wiki/South_Island" title="South Island">South Island</a> of New Zealand</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Puncakjaya.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Puncakjaya.jpg/220px-Puncakjaya.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Puncakjaya.jpg/330px-Puncakjaya.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Puncakjaya.jpg/440px-Puncakjaya.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Puncakjaya.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Puncak_Jaya" title="Puncak Jaya">Puncak Jaya</a> / <i>Carstensz Pyramid</i>, highest summit in Oceania</div></div></div>
<p>Under a four subregion model, the islands of Oceania extend to New Guinea in the west, the <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">Bonin Islands</a> in the northwest, the <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands" title="Hawaiian Islands">Hawaiʻian Islands</a> in the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isla_Salas_y_G%C3%B3mez" title="Isla Salas y Gómez">Sala y Gómez Island</a> in the east, and <a href="/wiki/Macquarie_Island" title="Macquarie Island">Macquarie Island</a> in the south. Excluded under most definitions of Oceania are the Pacific landmasses of <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands">Ryukyu Islands</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_archipelago" title="Japanese archipelago">Japanese archipelago</a>, which are all on the margins of Asia, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Aleutian_Islands" title="Aleutian Islands">Aleutian Islands</a> and other Alaskan or Canadian islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nz_87-2"><a href="#cite_note-nz-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ev_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-ev-203">[203]</a></sup> In its periphery, Oceania's islands would sprawl <a href="/wiki/28th_parallel_north" title="28th parallel north">28 degrees north</a> to the Bonin Islands in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_hemisphere" title="Northern hemisphere">northern hemisphere</a>, and <a href="/wiki/55th_parallel_south" title="55th parallel south">55 degrees south</a> to Macquarie Island in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southern_hemisphere" title="Southern hemisphere">southern hemisphere</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-race1750_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-race1750-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>Oceanian islands are of four basic types: continental islands, <a href="/wiki/High_island" title="High island">high islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reefs</a> and uplifted <a href="/wiki/Coral_island" title="Coral island">coral platforms</a>. High islands are of volcanic origin, and many contain active volcanoes. Among these are <a href="/wiki/Bougainville_Island" title="Bougainville Island">Bougainville</a>, Hawaiʻi, and Solomon Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GillespieClague2009_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-GillespieClague2009-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>Oceania is one of eight terrestrial <a href="/wiki/Biogeographic_realm" title="Biogeographic realm">biogeographic realms</a>, which constitute the major ecological regions of the planet. Related to these concepts are <a href="/wiki/Near_Oceania" title="Near Oceania">Near Oceania</a>, that part of western <a href="/wiki/Island_Melanesia" title="Island Melanesia">Island Melanesia</a> which has been inhabited for tens of millennia, and <a href="/wiki/Remote_Oceania" title="Remote Oceania">Remote Oceania</a> which is more recently settled. Although the majority of the Oceanian islands lie in the South Pacific, a few of them are not restricted to the Pacific Ocean – <a href="/wiki/Kangaroo_Island" title="Kangaroo Island">Kangaroo Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ashmore_and_Cartier_Islands" title="Ashmore and Cartier Islands">Ashmore and Cartier Islands</a>, for instance, are situated in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ocean" title="Southern Ocean">Southern Ocean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>, respectively, and <a href="/wiki/West_Coast,_Tasmania" title="West Coast, Tasmania">Tasmania's west coast</a> faces the Southern Ocean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-othero5_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-othero5-206">[206]</a></sup>
The coral reefs of the South Pacific are low-lying structures that have built up on basaltic lava flows under the ocean's surface. One of the most dramatic is the <a href="/wiki/Great_Barrier_Reef" title="Great Barrier Reef">Great Barrier Reef</a> off northeastern Australia with chains of reef patches. A second island type formed of coral is the uplifted coral platform, which is usually slightly larger than the low coral islands. Examples include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Banaba_Island" title="Banaba Island">Banaba</a> (formerly Ocean Island) and <a href="/wiki/Makatea" title="Makatea">Makatea</a> in the Tuamotu group of <a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britta_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-britta-207">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abcnet22613_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-abcnet22613-208">[208]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="446" data-file-width="650" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg/330px-%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg/495px-%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a8/%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%22Political_Oceania%22_CIA_World_Factbook.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of Oceania from the CIA World Factbook</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oceania_Political_Map_(EEZ_based).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="834" data-file-width="1347" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Oceania_Political_Map_%28EEZ_based%29.png/330px-Oceania_Political_Map_%28EEZ_based%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Oceania_Political_Map_%28EEZ_based%29.png/495px-Oceania_Political_Map_%28EEZ_based%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Oceania_Political_Map_%28EEZ_based%29.png/660px-Oceania_Political_Map_%28EEZ_based%29.png 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oceania_Political_Map_(EEZ_based).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">Exclusive economic zones</a> of Pacific states and territories</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regions">Regions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Regions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Micronesia" title="Micronesia">Micronesia</a>, which lies north of the equator and west of the <a href="/wiki/International_Date_Line" title="International Date Line">International Date Line</a>, includes the <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Islands" title="Mariana Islands">Mariana Islands</a> in the northwest, the <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Islands" title="Caroline Islands">Caroline Islands</a> in the center, the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands" title="Marshall Islands">Marshall Islands</a> to the west and the islands of <a href="/wiki/Kiribati" title="Kiribati">Kiribati</a> in the southeast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AAE_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-AAE-209">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LalFortune2000p63_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-LalFortune2000p63-210">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesia</a>, to the southwest, includes <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a>, the world's second largest island after <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> and by far the largest of the Pacific islands. The other main Melanesian groups from north to south are the <a href="/wiki/Maluku_Islands" title="Maluku Islands">Maluku Islands Archipelago</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bismarck_Archipelago" title="Bismarck Archipelago">Bismarck Archipelago</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands_(archipelago)" title="Solomon Islands (archipelago)">Solomon Islands archipelago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Islands" title="Santa Cruz Islands">Santa Cruz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-West2009_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-West2009-211">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Polynesia" title="Polynesia">Polynesia</a>, stretching from Hawaiʻi in the north to New Zealand in the south, also encompasses <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tokelau" title="Tokelau">Tokelau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samoa" title="Samoa">Samoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kermadec_Islands" title="Kermadec Islands">Kermadec Islands</a> to the west, the <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Society_Islands" title="Society Islands">Society Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austral_Islands" title="Austral Islands">Austral Islands</a> in the center, and the <a href="/wiki/Marquesas_Islands" title="Marquesas Islands">Marquesas Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuamotus" title="Tuamotus">Tuamotu</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mangareva_Islands" title="Mangareva Islands">Mangareva Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a> to the east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DunfordRidgell1996_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-DunfordRidgell1996-212">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Australasia" title="Australasia">Australasia</a> comprises Australia, New Zealand, the island of <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a>, and neighbouring islands in the Pacific Ocean. Along with India most of Australasia lies on the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a> with the latter occupying the Southern area. It is flanked by the Indian Ocean to the west and the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ocean" title="Southern Ocean">Southern Ocean</a> to the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voyage6_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-voyage6-213">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auxter_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-auxter-214">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">Geology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Geology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Fiji" title="Geography of Fiji">Geography of Fiji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_New_Zealand" title="Geology of New Zealand">Geology of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Australia" title="Geology of Australia">Geology of Australia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Samoa" title="Geography of Samoa">Geography of Samoa</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plaque_Pacifique.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1134" data-file-width="1134" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Plaque_Pacifique.JPG/220px-Plaque_Pacifique.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Plaque_Pacifique.JPG/330px-Plaque_Pacifique.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Plaque_Pacifique.JPG/440px-Plaque_Pacifique.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plaque_Pacifique.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">Pacific Plate</a> comprises most of Oceania, excluding <a href="/wiki/Australasia" title="Australasia">Australasia</a> and the western portion of <a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">Pacific Plate</a>, which makes up most of Oceania, is an oceanic <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">tectonic plate</a> that lies beneath the Pacific Ocean. At 103 million square kilometres (40,000,000 sq mi), it is the largest tectonic plate. The plate contains an interior <a href="/wiki/Hotspot_(geology)" title="Hotspot (geology)">hot spot</a> forming the <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands" title="Hawaiian Islands">Hawaiʻian Islands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tecto_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-tecto-215">[215]</a></sup> It is almost entirely <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust">oceanic crust</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-platetec2010_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-platetec2010-216">[216]</a></sup> The oldest member disappearing by way of the <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">plate tectonics</a> cycle is early-<a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a> (145 to 137 million years ago).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ageof_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-ageof-217">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>Australia, being part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_plate" title="Indo-Australian plate">Indo-Australian plate</a>, is the lowest, flattest, and oldest landmass on Earth<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-distinct227_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-distinct227-218">[218]</a></sup> and it has had a relatively stable geological history. Geological forces such as <a href="/wiki/Tectonic_uplift" title="Tectonic uplift">tectonic uplift</a> of mountain ranges or clashes between tectonic plates occurred mainly in Australia's early history, when it was still a part of <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>. Australia is situated in the middle of the tectonic plate, and therefore currently has no active volcanism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ag_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-ag-219">[219]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Geology" title="Geology">geology</a> of New Zealand is noted for its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volcanic" title="Volcanic">volcanic</a> activity, <a href="/wiki/Earthquake" title="Earthquake">earthquakes</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geothermal" title="Geothermal">geothermal</a> <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_areas_in_New_Zealand" title="Geothermal areas in New Zealand">areas</a> because of its position on the boundary of the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Plate" title="Australian Plate">Australian Plate</a> and Pacific Plates. Much of the basement rock of New Zealand was once part of the super-continent of Gondwana, along with South America, Africa, <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a>, India, Antarctica and Australia. The rocks that now form the continent of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zealandia_(continent)" title="Zealandia (continent)">Zealandia</a> were nestled between Eastern Australia and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Antarctica" title="Western Antarctica">Western Antarctica</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tearaz_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-tearaz-220">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Australia-New Zealand continental fragment of Gondwana split from the rest of Gondwana in the <a href="/wiki/Late_Cretaceous" title="Late Cretaceous">late Cretaceous</a> time (95–90 Ma). By 75 Ma, Zealandia was essentially separate from Australia and Antarctica, although only shallow seas might have separated Zealandia and Australia in the north. The <a href="/wiki/Tasman_Sea" title="Tasman Sea">Tasman Sea</a>, and part of Zealandia then locked together with Australia to form the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Plate" title="Australian Plate">Australian Plate</a> (40 Ma), and a new plate boundary was created between the Australian Plate and Pacific Plate.
</p><p>Most islands in the Pacific are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_islands" title="High islands">high islands</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volcanic" title="Volcanic">volcanic</a> islands), such as, <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_Samoa" title="American Samoa">American Samoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>, among others, having peaks up to 1300 m rising abruptly from the shore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Factbook-Fiji_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-Factbook-Fiji-221">[221]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Hawaiian_Islands" title="Northwestern Hawaiian Islands">Northwestern Hawaiʻian Islands</a> were formed <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 7 to 30 million years ago, as <a href="/wiki/Shield_volcano" title="Shield volcano">shield volcanoes</a> over the same volcanic <a href="/wiki/Hotspot_(geology)" title="Hotspot (geology)">hotspot</a> that formed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_Seamounts" title="Emperor Seamounts">Emperor Seamounts</a> to the north and the Main Hawaiʻian Islands to the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-geochr_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-geochr-222">[222]</a></sup> Hawaiʻi's tallest mountain <a href="/wiki/Mauna_Kea" title="Mauna Kea">Mauna Kea</a> is 4,205 m (13,796 ft) above mean sea level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-usgsgov_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-usgsgov-223">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flora">Flora</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Flora">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
