<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Australia" title="Geography of Australia">Geography of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_New_Zealand" title="Environment of New Zealand">Environment of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Australia" title="Flora of Australia">Flora of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_New_Zealand" title="Flora of New Zealand">Flora of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Endemism_in_the_Hawaiian_Islands" title="Endemism in the Hawaiian Islands">Endemism in the Hawaiian Islands</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domesticated_plants_of_Austronesia" title="Domesticated plants of Austronesia">Domesticated plants of Austronesia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Countryside_Kaikoura,_New_Zealand.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Countryside_Kaikoura%2C_New_Zealand.JPG/220px-Countryside_Kaikoura%2C_New_Zealand.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Countryside_Kaikoura%2C_New_Zealand.JPG/330px-Countryside_Kaikoura%2C_New_Zealand.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Countryside_Kaikoura%2C_New_Zealand.JPG/440px-Countryside_Kaikoura%2C_New_Zealand.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Countryside_Kaikoura,_New_Zealand.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>New Zealand countryside</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_(Ayers_Rock),_Sunset.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2233" data-file-width="3573" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_%28Ayers_Rock%29%2C_Sunset.jpg/220px-Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_%28Ayers_Rock%29%2C_Sunset.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_%28Ayers_Rock%29%2C_Sunset.jpg/330px-Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_%28Ayers_Rock%29%2C_Sunset.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_%28Ayers_Rock%29%2C_Sunset.jpg/440px-Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_%28Ayers_Rock%29%2C_Sunset.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu_(Ayers_Rock),_Sunset.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Uluru" title="Uluru">Uluru</a> (Ayers Rock) in <a href="/wiki/Central_Australia" title="Central Australia">Central Australia</a></div></div></div>
<p>The most diverse country of Oceania when it comes to the environment is Australia, with tropical <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforests</a> in the north-east, mountain ranges in the south-east, south-west and east, and dry desert in the centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-envigov2012_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-envigov2012-224">[224]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Deserts_of_Australia" title="Deserts of Australia">Desert</a> or semi-arid land commonly known as the <a href="/wiki/Outback" title="Outback">outback</a> makes up by far the largest portion of land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-portrait_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-portrait-225">[225]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Australian_temperate_forests" title="Eastern Australian temperate forests">coastal uplands</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Brigalow_Belt" title="Brigalow Belt">belt of Brigalow grasslands</a> lie between the coast and the mountains, while inland of the dividing range are large areas of grassland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drivers375_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-drivers375-226">[226]</a></sup> The northernmost point of the east coast is the tropical-rainforested <a href="/wiki/Cape_York_Peninsula" title="Cape York Peninsula">Cape York Peninsula</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uplands_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-uplands-227">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gdowns_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-gdowns-228">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mulgas_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-mulgas-229">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tempera_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-tempera-230">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-savanna_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-savanna-231">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>Prominent features of the Australian flora are adaptations to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aridity" title="Aridity">aridity</a> and fire which include <a href="/wiki/Sclerophyll" title="Sclerophyll">scleromorphy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serotiny" title="Serotiny">serotiny</a>. These adaptations are common in species from the large and well-known families <a href="/wiki/Proteaceae" title="Proteaceae">Proteaceae</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Banksia" title="Banksia">Banksia</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Myrtaceae" title="Myrtaceae">Myrtaceae</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Eucalyptus" title="Eucalyptus">Eucalyptus</a></i> – gum trees), and <a href="/wiki/Fabaceae" title="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Acacia" title="Acacia">Acacia</a></i> – wattle). The flora of Fiji, <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_dry_forest" title="Tropical dry forest">tropical dry forest</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Tropical_vegetation" title="Tropical vegetation">tropical vegetation</a> that includes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palm_trees" title="Palm trees">palm trees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Premna_protrusa" title="Premna protrusa">premna protrusa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Psydrax_odorata" title="Psydrax odorata">psydrax odorata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gyrocarpus_americanus" title="Gyrocarpus americanus">gyrocarpus americanus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Derris_trifoliata" title="Derris trifoliata">derris trifoliata</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mostvb_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-mostvb-232">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>New Zealand's landscape ranges from the <a href="/wiki/Fjord" title="Fjord">fjord</a>-like sounds of the southwest to the tropical beaches of the far north. South Island is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Alps" title="Southern Alps">Southern Alps</a>. There are 18 peaks of more than 3000 metres (9800 ft) in the South Island. All summits over 2,900 m are within the Southern Alps, a chain that forms the backbone of the South Island; the highest peak of which is <a href="/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook" title="Aoraki / Mount Cook">Aoraki / Mount Cook</a>, at 3,754 metres (12,316 ft). Earthquakes are common, though usually not severe, averaging 3,000 per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newzat_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-newzat-233">[233]</a></sup> There is a wide variety of native trees, adapted to all the various micro-climates in New Zealand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vascplant_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-vascplant-234">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Hawaiʻi, one endemic plant, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brighamia" title="Brighamia">Brighamia</a></i>, now requires hand-pollination because its natural pollinator is presumed to be extinct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-plantprop_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-plantprop-235">[235]</a></sup> The two species of <i>Brighamia</i> – <i>B. rockii</i> and <i>B. insignis</i> – are represented in the wild by around 120 individual plants. To ensure these plants set seed, biologists rappel down 910-metre (3,000 ft) cliffs to brush pollen onto their stigmas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forgotpol_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-forgotpol-236">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fauna">Fauna</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Fauna">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Australia" title="Fauna of Australia">Fauna of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Birds_of_Australia" title="Birds of Australia">Birds of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Birds_of_New_Zealand" title="Birds of New Zealand">Birds of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_New_Zealand" title="Fauna of New Zealand">Fauna of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mammals_of_Australia" title="Mammals of Australia">Mammals of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Australia" title="List of birds of Australia">List of birds of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_New_Zealand" title="List of birds of New Zealand">List of birds of New Zealand</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Domesticated_animals_of_Austronesia" title="Domesticated animals of Austronesia">Domesticated animals of Austronesia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Norfolk_Robin_(Petroica_multicolor)_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2260" data-file-width="1577" decoding="async" height="244" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Norfolk_Robin_%28Petroica_multicolor%29_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg/170px-Norfolk_Robin_%28Petroica_multicolor%29_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Norfolk_Robin_%28Petroica_multicolor%29_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg/255px-Norfolk_Robin_%28Petroica_multicolor%29_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Norfolk_Robin_%28Petroica_multicolor%29_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg/340px-Norfolk_Robin_%28Petroica_multicolor%29_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Norfolk_Robin_(Petroica_multicolor)_in_the_Norfolk_Island.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Pacific_robin" title="Pacific robin">Pacific robin</a> inhabits the islands of the south western Pacific.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IUCN_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-237">[237]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The aptly named <a href="/wiki/Pacific_kingfisher" title="Pacific kingfisher">Pacific kingfisher</a> is found in the Pacific Islands,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handbirds_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-handbirds-238">[238]</a></sup> as is the <a href="/wiki/Red-vented_bulbul" title="Red-vented bulbul">Red-vented bulbul</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-icunet22717_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-icunet22717-239">[239]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_starling" title="Polynesian starling">Polynesian starling</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hawaiibirds_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-hawaiibirds-240">[240]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brown_goshawk" title="Brown goshawk">Brown goshawk</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birdsback_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-birdsback-241">[241]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Swallow" title="Pacific Swallow">Pacific Swallow</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turner_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Turner-242">[242]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_myzomela" title="Cardinal myzomela">Cardinal myzomela</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cardinal_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-cardinal-243">[243]</a></sup> Birds breeding on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pitcairn" title="Pitcairn">Pitcairn</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Fairy_tern" title="Fairy tern">fairy tern</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_noddy" title="Common noddy">common noddy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Red-tailed_tropicbird" title="Red-tailed tropicbird">red-tailed tropicbird</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_reed_warbler" title="Pitcairn reed warbler">Pitcairn reed warbler</a>, endemic to Pitcairn Island, was added to the <a href="/wiki/Endangered_species" title="Endangered species">endangered species</a> list in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-icunred181023_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-icunred181023-244">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>Native to Hawaiʻi is the <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_crow" title="Hawaiian crow">Hawaiian crow</a>, which has been <a href="/wiki/Extinct_in_the_wild" title="Extinct in the wild">extinct in the wild</a> since 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forestbirds_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-forestbirds-245">[245]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brown_tree_snake" title="Brown tree snake">brown tree snake</a> is native to northern and eastern coasts of Australia, Papua New Guinea, Guam and Solomon Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-btsnakegov_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-btsnakegov-246">[246]</a></sup> Native to Australia, New Guinea and proximate islands are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birds_of_paradise" title="Birds of paradise">birds of paradise</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honeyeater" title="Honeyeater">honeyeaters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australasian_treecreeper" title="Australasian treecreeper">Australasian treecreeper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australasian_robin" title="Australasian robin">Australasian robin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingfisher" title="Kingfisher">kingfishers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Butcherbird" title="Butcherbird">butcherbirds</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bowerbird" title="Bowerbird">bowerbirds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-systax_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-systax-247">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Steadman_2006_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-Steadman_2006-248">[248]</a></sup>
</p><p>A unique feature of Australia's fauna is the relative scarcity of native <a href="/wiki/Placentalia" title="Placentalia">placental</a> mammals, and dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Marsupial" title="Marsupial">marsupials</a> – a group of mammals that raise their young in a <a href="/wiki/Pouch_(marsupial)" title="Pouch (marsupial)">pouch</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Macropodidae" title="Macropodidae">macropods</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phalangeriformes" title="Phalangeriformes">possums</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dasyuromorphia" title="Dasyuromorphia">dasyuromorphs</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Passerine" title="Passerine">passerines</a> of Australia, also known as songbirds or perching birds, include <a href="/wiki/Wren" title="Wren">wrens</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Artamidae" title="Artamidae">magpie group</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acanthiza" title="Acanthiza">thornbills</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Corvid" title="Corvid">corvids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pardalote" title="Pardalote">pardalotes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lyrebird" title="Lyrebird">lyrebirds</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ioc_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-ioc-249">[249]</a></sup> Predominant bird species in the country include the <a href="/wiki/Australian_magpie" title="Australian magpie">Australian magpie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australian_raven" title="Australian raven">Australian raven</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pied_currawong" title="Pied currawong">pied currawong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crested_pigeon" title="Crested pigeon">crested pigeons</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Laughing_kookaburra" title="Laughing kookaburra">laughing kookaburra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encycwild_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-encycwild-250">[250]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Koala" title="Koala">koala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emu" title="Emu">emu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Platypus" title="Platypus">platypus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kangaroo" title="Kangaroo">kangaroo</a> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_animals" title="National animals">national animals</a> of Australia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CoatArms_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-CoatArms-251">[251]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Tasmanian_devil" title="Tasmanian devil">Tasmanian devil</a> is also one of the well-known animals in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tassie_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-tassie-252">[252]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Goanna" title="Goanna">goanna</a> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Predatory" title="Predatory">predatory</a> lizard native to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australian_mainland" title="Australian mainland">Australian mainland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dangerc_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-dangerc-253">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>The birds of New Zealand evolved into an avifauna that included a large number of <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a> species. As an island archipelago New Zealand accumulated bird diversity and when Captain James Cook arrived in the 1770s he noted that the <a href="/wiki/Bird_vocalization" title="Bird vocalization">bird song</a> was deafening. The mix includes species with unusual biology such as the <a href="/wiki/K%C4%81k%C4%81p%C5%8D" title="Kākāpō">kākāpō</a> which is the world's only flightless, nocturnal, <a href="/wiki/Lek_mating" title="Lek mating">lek-breeding</a> parrot, but also many species that are similar to neighboring land areas. Some of the more well known and distinctive bird species in New Zealand are the <a href="/wiki/Kiwi_(bird)" title="Kiwi (bird)">kiwi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kea" title="Kea">kea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Takah%C4%93" title="Takahē">takahē</a>, kakapo, <a href="/wiki/Yellowhead_(bird)" title="Yellowhead (bird)">mohua</a>, <a href="/wiki/T%C5%AB%C4%AB" title="Tūī">tūī</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_bellbird" title="New Zealand bellbird">bellbird</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-assemb152_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-assemb152-254">[254]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tuatara" title="Tuatara">tuatara</a> is a notable <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptile</a> endemic to New Zealand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vicvag32_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-vicvag32-255">[255]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Australia" title="Climate of Australia">Climate of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_New_Zealand" title="Climate of New Zealand">Climate of New Zealand</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Hawaii" title="Climate of Hawaii">Climate of Hawaii</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Church,_Dunedin,_NZ.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3253" data-file-width="3637" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/First_Church%2C_Dunedin%2C_NZ.jpg/220px-First_Church%2C_Dunedin%2C_NZ.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/First_Church%2C_Dunedin%2C_NZ.jpg/330px-First_Church%2C_Dunedin%2C_NZ.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/First_Church%2C_Dunedin%2C_NZ.jpg/440px-First_Church%2C_Dunedin%2C_NZ.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Church,_Dunedin,_NZ.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>August 2011 winter's snowfall in <a href="/wiki/Dunedin" title="Dunedin">Dunedin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otago" title="Otago">Otago</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Pacific Islands are ruled by a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_rainforest" title="Tropical rainforest">tropical rainforest</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tropical_savanna_climate" title="Tropical savanna climate">tropical savanna climate</a>. In the tropical and subtropical Pacific, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o_Southern_Oscillation" title="El Niño Southern Oscillation">El Niño Southern Oscillation</a> (ENSO) affects weather conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-noaagov_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-noaagov-256">[256]</a></sup> In the tropical western Pacific, the <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> and the related <a href="/wiki/Wet_season" title="Wet season">wet season</a> during the summer months contrast with dry winds in the winter which blow over the ocean from the Asian landmass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allenp2009_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-allenp2009-257">[257]</a></sup> November is the only month in which all the <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_basins" title="Tropical cyclone basins">tropical cyclone basins</a> are active.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AOML_FAQ_G1_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-AOML_FAQ_G1-258">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>To the southwest of the region, in the Australian landmass, the climate is mostly desert or <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid</a>, with the southern coastal corners having a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperateness" title="Temperateness">temperate</a> climate, such as <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical" title="Humid subtropical">humid subtropical</a> climate in the east coast and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> in the west. The northern parts of the country have a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical climate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-climatea_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-climatea-259">[259]</a></sup> Snow falls frequently on the highlands near the east coast, in the states of <a href="/wiki/Victoria_(Australia)" title="Victoria (Australia)">Victoria</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_South_Wales" title="New South Wales">New South Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tasmania" title="Tasmania">Tasmania</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Capital_Territory" title="Australian Capital Territory">Australian Capital Territory</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-precip376_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-precip376-260">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most regions of New Zealand belong to the temperate zone with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maritime_climate" title="Maritime climate">maritime climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>: Cfb) characterised by four distinct seasons. Conditions vary from extremely wet on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Coast,_New_Zealand" title="West Coast, New Zealand">West Coast</a> of the <a href="/wiki/South_Island" title="South Island">South Island</a> to almost <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid</a> in <a href="/wiki/Central_Otago" title="Central Otago">Central Otago</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">subtropical</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Auckland_Peninsula" title="North Auckland Peninsula">Northland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-enviclim_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-enviclim-261">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-niwaco_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-niwaco-262">[262]</a></sup> Snow falls in New Zealand's <a href="/wiki/South_Island" title="South Island">South Island</a> and at higher altitudes in the <a href="/wiki/North_Island" title="North Island">North Island</a>. It is extremely rare at sea level in the North Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tele141116_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-tele141116-263">[263]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hawaiʻi, although being in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropic" title="Tropic">tropics</a>, experiences many different climates, depending on latitude and its geography. The <a href="/wiki/Hawaii_(island)" title="Hawaii (island)">island of Hawaiʻi</a> for example hosts 4 (out of 5 in total) climate groups on a surface as small as 10,430 km<sup>2</sup> (4,028 sq mi) according to the Köppen climate types: tropical, arid, temperate and polar. The Hawaiʻian Islands receive most of their precipitation during the winter months (October to April).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loveb20120703_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-loveb20120703-264">[264]</a></sup> A few islands in the northwest, such as <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a>, are susceptible to <a href="/wiki/Typhoon" title="Typhoon">typhoons</a> in the wet season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pubaff042700_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-pubaff042700-265">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>The highest recorded temperature in Oceania occurred in <a href="/wiki/Oodnadatta" title="Oodnadatta">Oodnadatta</a>, South Australia (2 January 1960), where the temperature reached 50.7 °C (123.3 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bomgovdai_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-bomgovdai-266">[266]</a></sup> The lowest temperature ever recorded in Oceania was −25.6 °C (−14.1 °F), at <a href="/wiki/Ranfurly,_New_Zealand" title="Ranfurly, New Zealand">Ranfurly</a> in Otago in 1903, with a more recent temperature of −21.6 °C (−6.9 °F) recorded in 1995 in nearby <a href="/wiki/Ophir,_New_Zealand" title="Ophir, New Zealand">Ophir</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herald120611_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-herald120611-267">[267]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pohnpei" title="Pohnpei">Pohnpei</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Senyavin_Islands" title="Senyavin Islands">Senyavin Islands</a> in <a href="/wiki/Micronesia" title="Micronesia">Micronesia</a> is the wettest settlement in Oceania, and one of the wettest places on earth, with annual recorded rainfall exceeding 7,600 mm (300 in) each year in certain mountainous locations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-werigu_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-werigu-268">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Big_Bog,_Maui" title="Big Bog, Maui">The Big Bog</a> on the island of Maui is the wettest place, receiving an average 10,271 mm (404.4 in) each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-matology105_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-matology105-269">[269]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1021810730">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery{width:100%!important}}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery{display:table}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-default{background:transparent;margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-center{margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-left{float:left}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-right{float:right}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-none{float:none}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery-collapsible{width:100%}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .title,.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .main,.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .footer{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .title>div{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0 0.6em 1.6em;text-align:center;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .main>div{display:table-cell}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .gallery{line-height:1.35em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .footer>div{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0 0.6em 1.6em;text-align:right;font-size:80%;line-height:1em}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .title>div *,.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .footer>div *{overflow:visible}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .gallerybox img{background:none!important}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .bordered-images .thumb img{border:solid #eaecf0 1px}.mw-parser-output .mod-gallery .whitebg .thumb{background:#fff!important}</style><div class="mod-gallery mod-gallery-default mod-gallery-center"><div class="title"><div>Köppen climate classification of selected regions in Oceania</div></div><div class="main"><div><ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional nochecker bordered-images whitebg">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Oceania" title="Demographics of Oceania">Demographics of Oceania</a></div>
<p>The linked map below shows the <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zones</a> (EEZs) of the islands of Oceania and neighbouring areas, as a guide to the following table (there are few land boundaries that can be drawn on a map of the Pacific at this scale).
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 750px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EEZ_Oceania.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="215" data-file-width="385" decoding="async" height="419" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/EEZ_Oceania.svg/750px-EEZ_Oceania.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/EEZ_Oceania.svg/1125px-EEZ_Oceania.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/EEZ_Oceania.svg/1500px-EEZ_Oceania.svg.png 2x" width="750"/></a>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:304.5px; top:194.5px"><a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands"><span style="color:white;">Solomon<br/>Islands</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:417px; top:194.5px"><a href="/wiki/Tokelau" title="Tokelau">Tokelau</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:327px; top:109px"><a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands" title="Marshall Islands">Marshall<br/>Islands</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:324.75px; top:158.5px"><a href="/wiki/Nauru" title="Nauru">Nauru</a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:403.5px; top:214.75px"><a href="/wiki/Wallis_and_Futuna" title="Wallis and Futuna">WF</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:437.25px; top:241.75px"><a href="/wiki/Niue" title="Niue">Niue</a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:57px; top:205.75px"><a href="/wiki/Christmas_Island" title="Christmas Island">Christmas</a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:151.5px; top:32.5px"><a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands"><span style="color:white;">Ryukyu</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:219px; top:19px"><a href="/wiki/Izu_Islands" title="Izu Islands"><span style="color:white;">Izu</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:219px; top:37px"><a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands"><span style="color:white;">Bonin</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:219px; top:55px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iwo_Islands" title="Iwo Islands"><span style="color:white;">Iwo</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:192px; top:64px"><a href="/wiki/Okinotorishima" title="Okinotorishima"><span style="color:white;">Okinotori<br/>shima</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:268.5px; top:52.75px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marcus_Island" title="Marcus Island"><span style="color:white;">Marcus</span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:394.5px; top:32.5px"><a href="/wiki/Midway_Atoll" title="Midway Atoll">Midway</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:428.25px; top:77.5px"><a href="/wiki/Johnston_Atoll" title="Johnston Atoll">Johnston</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:693.75px; top:104.5px"><a href="/wiki/Clipperton_Island" title="Clipperton Island">Clipperton</a></div>

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:401.25px; top:147.25px"><a href="/wiki/Howland_Island" title="Howland Island">Howland</a></div>

</div>
<p>The demographic table below shows the subregions and countries of geopolitical Oceania. The countries and territories in this table are categorised according to the scheme for geographic subregions used by the United Nations. The information shown follows sources in cross-referenced articles; where sources differ, provisos have been clearly indicated. These territories and regions are subject to various additional categorisations, depending on the source and purpose of each description.
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="border:1px solid #aaa; font-size:90%;">

</th>

</th>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_city_for_regions">Largest city for regions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Largest city for regions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Australasia" title="Australasia">Australasia</a> (metro, urban or proper largest city: <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesia</a> (metro, urban or proper largest city: <a href="/wiki/Port_Moresby" title="Port Moresby">Port Moresby</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Micronesia" title="Micronesia">Micronesia</a> (metro, urban or proper largest city: <a href="/wiki/Tarawa" title="Tarawa">Tarawa</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Polynesia" title="Polynesia">Polynesia</a> (metro, urban or proper largest city: <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">Auckland</a>)</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cities_by_metropolitan_area">Cities by metropolitan area</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Cities by metropolitan area">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">

<th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0.75em;"><div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em"> </div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Largest_metropolitan_cities_of_Oceania" title="Template:Largest metropolitan cities of Oceania"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Template_talk:Largest_metropolitan_cities_of_Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Template talk:Largest metropolitan cities of Oceania (page does not exist)"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_metropolitan_cities_of_Oceania&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div> <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;"><span style="font-size:110%;">Largest population centres of Oceania</span><br/><div style="display:inline;font-weight:normal;"><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup>June 2021 estimate (<abbr title="Statistical Standard for Geographic Areas 2018)">SSGA18</abbr> boundaries)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_population_data_2018_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-NZ_population_data_2018-283">[283]</a></sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USCB_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-USCB-284">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup></div></div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Oceania" title="Religion in Oceania">Religion in Oceania</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saione.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Saione.jpg/220px-Saione.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Saione.jpg/330px-Saione.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Saione.jpg/440px-Saione.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saione.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Saione, the church of the King, a <a href="/wiki/Free_Wesleyan_Church_of_Tonga" title="Free Wesleyan Church of Tonga">Free Wesleyan Church</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kolomotu%CA%BBa" title="Kolomotuʻa">Kolomotuʻa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>. Especially British and American missionaries brought various Protestant denominations to Oceania.</div></div></div>
<p>The predominant religion in Oceania is <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> (73%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christianity_in_Oceania_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christianity_in_Oceania-287">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_Dept_of_State_Background_Notes_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-US_Dept_of_State_Background_Notes-288">[288]</a></sup> A 2011 survey found that 92% in <a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">Melanesia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christianity_in_Oceania_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-Christianity_in_Oceania-287">[287]</a></sup> 93% in <a href="/wiki/Micronesia" title="Micronesia">Micronesia</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christianity_in_Oceania_287-2"><a href="#cite_note-Christianity_in_Oceania-287">[287]</a></sup> and 96% in <a href="/wiki/Polynesia" title="Polynesia">Polynesia</a> described themselves as <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christianity_in_Oceania_287-3"><a href="#cite_note-Christianity_in_Oceania-287">[287]</a></sup> Traditional religions are often <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">animist</a>, and prevalent among traditional tribes is the belief in spirits (<i>masalai</i> in <a href="/wiki/Tok_Pisin" title="Tok Pisin">Tok Pisin</a>) representing natural forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anthropology-Cowan-Messengers_of_the_Gods_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anthropology-Cowan-Messengers_of_the_Gods-289">[289]</a></sup> In the 2018 census, 37% of New Zealanders affiliated themselves with Christianity and 48% declared no religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-quickstats_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-quickstats-290">[290]</a></sup> In the 2016 Census, 52% of the Australian population declared some variety of Christianity and 30% stated "no religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reflect_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-reflect-291">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent Australian and New Zealand censuses, large proportions of the population say they belong to "<a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">no religion</a>" (which includes <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnosticism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deism" title="Deism">deism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secular_humanism" title="Secular humanism">secular humanism</a>). In <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>, everyday life is heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_culture" title="Polynesian culture">Polynesian</a> traditions and especially by the Christian faith. The <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> mosque in Marshall Islands is the only mosque in Micronesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mosque2011_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-mosque2011-292">[292]</a></sup> Another one in <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a> belongs to the same sect. The <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_House_of_Worship" title="Baháʼí House of Worship">Baháʼí House of Worship</a> in Tiapapata, <a href="/wiki/Samoa" title="Samoa">Samoa</a>, is one of seven designations administered in the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a>.
</p><p>Other religions in the region include <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, which are prominent <a href="/wiki/Minority_religion" title="Minority religion">minority religions</a> in Australia and New Zealand. <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> are also present. Sir <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Isaacs" title="Isaac Isaacs">Isaac Isaacs</a> was the first Australian-born <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Governor_General_of_Australia" title="Governor General of Australia">Governor General of Australia</a> and was the first Jewish vice-regal representative in the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausjew_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausjew-293">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_Philip_Movement" title="Prince Philip Movement">Prince Philip Movement</a> is followed around <a href="/wiki/Yaohnanen" title="Yaohnanen">Yaohnanen</a> village on the southern island of <a href="/wiki/Tanna_(island)" title="Tanna (island)">Tanna</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Languages">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Australia" title="Languages of Australia">Languages of Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_New_Zealand" title="Languages of New Zealand">Languages of New Zealand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Fiji" title="Languages of Fiji">Languages of Fiji</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Languages_of_Tonga" title="Languages of Tonga">Languages of Tonga</a></div>
<p>Native languages of Oceania fall into three major geographic groups:
</p>
<ul><li>The large <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian</a> <a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">language family</a>, with such languages as <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a> (Indonesian), and <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_languages" title="Oceanic languages">Oceanic languages</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Gilbertese_language" title="Gilbertese language">Gilbertese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fijian_language" title="Fijian language">Fijian</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language" title="Māori language">Māori</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_language" title="Hawaiian language">Hawaiʻian</a></li>
<li>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aboriginal_Australian_languages" title="Aboriginal Australian languages">Aboriginal Australian languages</a>, including the large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pama%E2%80%93Nyungan" title="Pama–Nyungan">Pama–Nyungan</a> family</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Papuan_languages" title="Papuan languages">Papuan languages</a> of <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a> and neighbouring islands, including the large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trans%E2%80%93New_Guinea" title="Trans–New Guinea">Trans–New Guinea</a> family</li></ul>
<p>Colonial languages include <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> in Australia, New Zealand, Hawaiʻi, and many other territories; <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wallis_and_Futuna" title="Wallis and Futuna">Wallis and Futuna</a>; Japanese in the <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">Bonin Islands</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-realm_58-3"><a href="#cite_note-realm-58">[58]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> on <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_Islands" title="Galápagos Islands">Galápagos Islands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-realm_58-4"><a href="#cite_note-realm-58">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ling_94-4"><a href="#cite_note-ling-94">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> There are also <a href="/wiki/Creole_language" title="Creole language">Creoles</a> formed from the interaction of Malay or the colonial languages with indigenous languages, such as <a href="/wiki/Tok_Pisin" title="Tok Pisin">Tok Pisin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bislama" title="Bislama">Bislama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">Chavacano</a>, various <a href="/wiki/Malay_trade_and_creole_languages" title="Malay trade and creole languages">Malay trade and creole languages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_Pidgin" title="Hawaiian Pidgin">Hawaiʻian Pidgin</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norfuk" title="Norfuk">Norfuk</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pitkern" title="Pitkern">Pitkern</a>. Contact between Austronesian and Papuan resulted in several instances in mixed languages such as <a href="/wiki/Maisin_language" title="Maisin language">Maisin</a>.
</p><p>Immigrants brought their own languages to the region, such as <a href="/wiki/Standard_Chinese" title="Standard Chinese">Mandarin</a>, Hindi, Italian, Arabic, Portuguese, Polish, German, Spanish, Russian, Korean, <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, among many others, namely in Australia and New Zealand,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-absgov20120621_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-absgov20120621-298">[298]</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Fiji_Hindi" title="Fiji Hindi">Fiji Hindi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Immigration">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Post-war_immigration_to_Australia" title="Post-war immigration to Australia">Post-war immigration to Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Australia" title="Immigration to Australia">Immigration to Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_New_Zealand" title="Immigration to New Zealand">Immigration to New Zealand</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refugees_in_Australia" title="Refugees in Australia">Refugees in Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Refugees_in_New_Zealand" title="Refugees in New Zealand">Refugees in New Zealand</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kanaka_(Pacific_Island_worker)" title="Kanaka (Pacific Island worker)">Kanaka (Pacific Island worker)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="343" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg/220px-Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg/330px-Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg/440px-Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dutch_Migrant_1954_MariaScholte%3D50000thToAustraliaPostWW2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dutch_Australians" title="Dutch Australians">Dutch</a> immigrants arriving in Australia (1954)</div></div></div>
<p>The most multicultural areas in Oceania, which have a <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_immigrant_population" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by immigrant population">high degree</a> of <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">immigration</a>, are Australia, New Zealand, and Hawaiʻi. Since 1945, more than 7 million people have settled in Australia. From the late 1970s, there was a significant increase in immigration from Asian and other non-European countries, making Australia a <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_Australia" title="Multiculturalism in Australia">multicultural country</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bureau181126_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-bureau181126-299">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sydney is the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multicultural" title="Multicultural">multicultural</a> city in Oceania, having more than 250 different languages spoken with about 40% of residents speaking a <a href="/wiki/Languages_Other_Than_English" title="Languages Other Than English">language other than English</a> at home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-herald231114_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-herald231114-300">[300]</a></sup> Furthermore, 36 percent of the population reported having been <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born" title="Foreign born">born overseas</a>, with top countries being Italy, Lebanon, Vietnam and Iraq, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheAus_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-TheAus-301">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population,_dwellings,_and_ethnicity_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-Population,_dwellings,_and_ethnicity-302">[302]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> is also fairly multicultural, having the largest <a href="/wiki/Greek_community_of_Melbourne" title="Greek community of Melbourne">Greek-speaking</a> population outside of Europe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd5024_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-oecd5024-303">[303]</a></sup> and the second largest <a href="/wiki/Asian_Australians" title="Asian Australians">Asian</a> population in Australia after Sydney.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indiandir_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-indiandir-304">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-srilandir_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-srilandir-305">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yarra062408_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-yarra062408-306">[306]</a></sup>
</p><p>European migration to New Zealand provided a major influx following the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi" title="Treaty of Waitangi">Treaty of Waitangi</a> in 1840. Subsequent immigration has been chiefly from the British Isles, but also from continental Europe, the Pacific, The Americas and Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parlnz1840_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-parlnz1840-307">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-immireg_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-immireg-308">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">Auckland</a> is home to over half (51.6 percent) of New Zealand's overseas born population, including 72 percent of the country's Pacific Island-born population, 64 percent of its <a href="/wiki/Asian_people" title="Asian people">Asian</a>-born population, and 56 percent of its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_people" title="Middle Eastern people">Middle Eastern</a> and African born population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013census_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013census-309">[309]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="629" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg/220px-Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg/330px-Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg/440px-Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portuguese_immigrant_family_in_Hawaii_during_the_19th_century.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Many <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Americans" title="Portuguese Americans">Portuguese</a> immigrants in Hawaiʻi were <a href="/wiki/Azores" title="Azores">Azorean</a> or <a href="/wiki/Madeira" title="Madeira">Madeiran</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Hawaiʻi is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Majority-minority_state" title="Majority-minority state">majority-minority state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuter013113_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuter013113-310">[310]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">Chinese</a> workers on Western trading ships settled in Hawaiʻi starting in 1789. In 1820, the first American missionaries arrived to preach Christianity and teach the Hawaiians Western ways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Charles_Williams_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-Charles_Williams-311">[311]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, a large proportion of Hawaiʻi's population have Asian ancestry – especially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_people" title="Filipino people">Filipino</a>, Japanese, <a href="/wiki/Korean_immigration_to_Hawaii" title="Korean immigration to Hawaii">Korean</a> and Chinese. Many are descendants of immigrants brought to work on the sugarcane plantations in the mid-to-late 19th century. Almost 13,000 <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> immigrants had arrived by 1899; they also worked on the <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a> plantations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hoffman_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hoffman-312">[312]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_immigration_to_Hawaii" title="Puerto Rican immigration to Hawaii">Puerto Rican immigration to Hawaiʻi</a> began in 1899 when Puerto Rico's sugar industry was devastated by two hurricanes, causing a worldwide shortage of sugar and a huge demand for sugar from Hawaiʻi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ricandias_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-ricandias-313">[313]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 2001 and 2007 Australia's <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Solution" title="Pacific Solution">Pacific Solution</a> policy transferred <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asylum_seekers" title="Asylum seekers">asylum seekers</a> to several Pacific nations, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nauru_detention_centre" title="Nauru detention centre">Nauru detention centre</a>. Australia, New Zealand and other nations took part in the <a href="/wiki/Regional_Assistance_Mission_to_Solomon_Islands" title="Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands">Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands</a> between 2003 and 2017 after a request for aid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bat_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-bat-314">[314]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Archaeogenetics">Archaeogenetics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Archaeogenetics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">Archaeology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Linguistics" title="Linguistics">linguistics</a>, and existing <a href="/wiki/Genetics" title="Genetics">genetic studies</a> indicate that Oceania was settled by two major waves of migration. The first migration of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australo-Melanesians" title="Australo-Melanesians">Australo-Melanesians</a> took place <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 40 to 80 thousand years ago, and these migrants, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Papuan_people" title="Papuan people">Papuans</a>, colonised much of <a href="/wiki/Near_Oceania" title="Near Oceania">Near Oceania</a>. Approximately 3.5 thousand years ago, a second expansion of <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian</a> speakers arrived in Near Oceania, and the descendants of these people spread to the far corners of the Pacific, colonising <a href="/wiki/Remote_Oceania" title="Remote Oceania">Remote Oceania</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-doi10.1016/j.ajhg.2014.03.014_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-doi10.1016/j.ajhg.2014.03.014-315">[315]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA" title="Mitochondrial DNA">Mitochondrial DNA</a> (mtDNA) studies quantify the magnitude of the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian expansion</a> and demonstrate the homogenising effect of this expansion. With regards to Papuan influence, autochthonous <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup" title="Haplogroup">haplogroups</a> support the hypothesis of a long history in Near Oceania, with some lineages suggesting a time depth of 60 thousand years. <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Islands" title="Santa Cruz Islands">Santa Cruz</a>, a population located in Remote Oceania, is an anomaly with extreme frequencies of autochthonous haplogroups of Near Oceanian origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-doi10.1016/j.ajhg.2014.03.014_315-1"><a href="#cite_note-doi10.1016/j.ajhg.2014.03.014-315">[315]</a></sup>
</p><p>Large areas of <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a> are unexplored by scientists and <a href="/wiki/Anthropologist" title="Anthropologist">anthropologists</a> due to extensive <a href="/wiki/Forestation" title="Forestation">forestation</a> and mountainous terrain. Known indigenous tribes in <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a> have very little contact with local authorities aside from the authorities knowing who they are. Many remain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Preliterate" title="Preliterate">preliterate</a> and, at the national or international level, the names of tribes and information about them is extremely hard to obtain. The <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesian</a> provinces of <a href="/wiki/Papua_(province)" title="Papua (province)">Papua</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Papua_(province)" title="West Papua (province)">West Papua</a> on the island of New Guinea are home to an estimated 44 <a href="/wiki/Uncontacted_peoples" title="Uncontacted peoples">uncontacted tribal groups</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-survival_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-survival-316">[316]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Oceania" title="Economy of Oceania">Economy of Oceania</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia_2">Australia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Australia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Australia" title="Economy of Australia">Economy of Australia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7008" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg/220px-Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg/330px-Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg/440px-Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sydney_skyline_from_Waverton_Balls_head_reserve.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Skyline_of_Sydney" title="Skyline of Sydney">skyline of Sydney</a></div></div></div>
<p>Australia and New Zealand are the only highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed</a> independent nations in the region, although the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Australia" title="Economy of Australia">economy of Australia</a> is by far the largest and most dominant economy in the region and one of the largest in the world. New Caledonia, Hawaiʻi, and French Polynesia are highly developed too but are not <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereign</a> states. Australia's per-capita GDP is <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">higher</a> than that of the UK, Canada, Germany, and France in terms of <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unstat228_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-unstat228-317">[317]</a></sup> New Zealand is also one of the most globalised economies and depends greatly on international trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stand260511_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-stand260511-318">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guard150411_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-guard150411-319">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Australian_Securities_Exchange" title="Australian Securities Exchange">Australian Securities Exchange</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sydney" title="Sydney">Sydney</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges_in_Oceania" title="List of stock exchanges in Oceania">stock exchange in Australia and in the South Pacific</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-if5com200514_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-if5com200514-320">[320]</a></sup> In 2012, Australia was the 12th largest national economy by nominal GDP and the 19th-largest measured by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP-adjusted</a> GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rbagov200514_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-rbagov200514-321">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mercer Quality of Living Survey ranks Sydney tenth in the world in terms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quality_of_living" title="Quality of living">quality of living</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mercer.com_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-mercer.com-322">[322]</a></sup> making it one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_most_livable_cities" title="World's most livable cities">most livable cities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mercer2014_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-mercer2014-323">[323]</a></sup> It is classified as an Alpha+ <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_City" title="World City">World City</a> by <a href="/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network" title="Globalization and World Cities Research Network">GaWC</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-accgawc_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-accgawc-324">[324]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urbanst_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-urbanst-325">[325]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> also ranked highly in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_Most_Livable_Cities" title="World's Most Livable Cities">world's most liveable city</a> list,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-melb181_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-melb181-326">[326]</a></sup> and is a leading <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" title="Asia-Pacific">Asia-Pacific</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-longfi041213_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-longfi041213-327">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-citindex_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-citindex-328">[328]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point,_Auckland_-_0365.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2490" data-file-width="4358" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point%2C_Auckland_-_0365.jpg/220px-Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point%2C_Auckland_-_0365.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point%2C_Auckland_-_0365.jpg/330px-Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point%2C_Auckland_-_0365.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point%2C_Auckland_-_0365.jpg/440px-Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point%2C_Auckland_-_0365.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Night_view_of_the_lit_city_of_Auckland_from_Northcote_Point,_Auckland_-_0365.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Auckland's <a href="/wiki/Auckland_CBD" title="Auckland CBD">central business district</a> at night.</div></div></div>
<p>The majority of people living in Australia work in health care, retail and education sectors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup> Australia boasts the largest amount of manufacturing in the region, <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Australia" title="Automotive industry in Australia">producing cars</a>, electrical equipment, machinery and <a href="/wiki/Clothing_industry" title="Clothing industry">clothes</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Zealand">New Zealand</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: New Zealand">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_New_Zealand" title="Economy of New Zealand">Economy of New Zealand</a></div>
<p>New Zealand's <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_New_Zealand" title="Economy of New Zealand">economy</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">53rd</a>-largest in the world measured by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_gross_domestic_product" title="Nominal gross domestic product">nominal gross domestic product</a> (GDP) and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">68th</a>-largest in the world measured by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP). A major economic and cultural powerhouse of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>, Auckland is ranked as a Beta+ world city by the <a href="/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network" title="Globalization and World Cities Research Network">Globalization and World Cities Research Network</a>. Auckland and <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">Wellington</a> are frequently ranked among the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_most_liveable_cities" title="World's most liveable cities">world's most liveable cities</a>, with Auckland being ranked <a href="/wiki/Global_Liveability_Ranking" title="Global Liveability Ranking">first in the world</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/Global_Liveability_Ranking" title="Global Liveability Ranking">Global Liveability Ranking</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-businrank_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-businrank-330">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mercer190214_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-mercer190214-331">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> has a large GDP for its population of 5.2 million, and sources of revenue are spread throughout the large island nation. The country has one of the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Globalised" title="Globalised">globalised</a> economies and depends greatly on international trade – mainly with <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>. New Zealand's 1983 <a href="/wiki/Closer_Economic_Relations" title="Closer Economic Relations">Closer Economic Relations</a> agreement with Australia means that the economy aligns closely with <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Australia" title="Economy of Australia">that of Australia</a>. In 2005, the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> praised New Zealand as the most business-friendly country in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SALE_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-SALE-332">[332]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IHT_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-IHT-333">[333]</a></sup> The economy diversified and by 2008, tourism had become the single biggest generator of foreign exchange.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diversify_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-diversify-334">[334]</a></sup> The New Zealand dollar is the 10th-most traded currency in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BIS_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-BIS-335">[335]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pacific_Islands">Pacific Islands</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Pacific Islands">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Fiji" title="Economy of Fiji">Economy of Fiji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Samoa" title="Economy of Samoa">Economy of Samoa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Tonga" title="Economy of Tonga">Economy of Tonga</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1129" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG/220px-Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG/330px-Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG/440px-Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Waikiki_view_from_Diamond_Head.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a> viewed from <a href="/wiki/Diamond_Head,_Hawaii" title="Diamond Head, Hawaii">Diamond Head</a> crater</div></div></div>
<p>The overwhelming majority of people living in the Pacific islands work in the service industry which includes tourism, education and financial services. Oceania's largest export markets include Japan, China, the United States and South Korea. The smallest Pacific nations rely on trade with Australia, New Zealand and the United States for exporting goods and for accessing other products. Australia and New Zealand's trading arrangements are known as <a href="/wiki/Closer_Economic_Relations" title="Closer Economic Relations">Closer Economic Relations</a>. Australia and New Zealand, along with other countries, are members of <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> (APEC) and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS), which may become trade blocs in the future particularly EAS.
</p><p>The main produce from the Pacific is <a href="/wiki/Copra" title="Copra">copra</a> or <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">coconut</a>, but <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timber" title="Timber">timber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palm_oil" title="Palm oil">palm oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a> are also commonly grown across the <a href="/wiki/Tropics" title="Tropics">tropics</a> of the Pacific. <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">Fishing</a> provides a major <a href="/wiki/Industry_(economics)" title="Industry (economics)">industry</a> for many of the smaller nations in the Pacific, although many <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishing</a> areas are exploited by other larger countries, namely Japan. <a href="/wiki/Natural_Resources" title="Natural Resources">Natural Resources</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nickel" title="Nickel">nickel</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, are mined in Australia and <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a>. Oceania's largest export markets include Japan, China, the United States, India, South Korea and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.
</p><p>Endowed with forest, mineral, and fish resources, <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> is one of the most developed of the Pacific island <a href="/wiki/Economics" title="Economics">economies</a>, though it remains a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developing_nation" title="Developing nation">developing country</a> with a large <a href="/wiki/Subsistence_agriculture" title="Subsistence agriculture">subsistence agriculture</a> sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ciafacfj_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-ciafacfj-336">[336]</a></sup> Agriculture accounts for 18% of <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a>, although it employed some 70% of the workforce as of 2001. <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">Sugar</a> exports and the growing tourist industry are the major sources of foreign exchange. Sugar cane processing makes up one-third of industrial activity. <a href="/wiki/Coconut" title="Coconut">Coconuts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Copra" title="Copra">copra</a> are also significant.
</p><p>The history of Hawaiʻi's economy can be traced through a succession of dominant industries; <a href="/wiki/Sandalwood" title="Sandalwood">sandalwood</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hawahis_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-hawahis-337">[337]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Whaling" title="Whaling">whaling</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-whalinhawa_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-whalinhawa-338">[338]</a></sup> sugarcane, <a href="/wiki/Pineapple" title="Pineapple">pineapple</a>, the military, tourism and education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-capitagdf_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-capitagdf-339">[339]</a></sup> Hawaiʻian exports include food and clothing. These industries play a small role in the Hawaiʻian economy, due to the shipping distance to viable markets, such as the West Coast of the contiguous U.S. The state's food exports include coffee, macadamia nuts, pineapple, livestock, sugarcane and honey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hawabee_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-hawabee-340">[340]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Honolulu was ranked high on world livability rankings, and was also ranked as the 2nd safest city in the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MercerSurvey2015_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-MercerSurvey2015-341">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KITVSafestCity_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-KITVSafestCity-342">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
