<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg/220px-Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg/330px-Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg/440px-Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shangri-La_Fijian_Resort_15.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shangri-La%27s_Fijian_Resort" title="Shangri-La's Fijian Resort">Shangri-La's Fijian Resort</a></div></div></div>
<p>Tourists mostly come from Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Fiji#Tourism" title="Economy of Fiji">Fiji</a> currently attracts almost half a million tourists each year, more than a quarter of whom come from Australia. This has contributed $1 billion or more to Fiji's economy since 1995, but the Government of Fiji likely underestimates these figures due to the invisible economy inside the tourism industry.
</p><p>Vanuatu is widely recognised as one of the premier vacation destinations for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scuba_diver" title="Scuba diver">scuba divers</a> wishing to explore <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reefs</a> of the South Pacific region. Tourism has been promoted, in part, by Vanuatu being the site of several reality-TV shows. The ninth season of the reality TV series <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Survivor_(US_TV_series)" title="Survivor (US TV series)">Survivor</a></i> was filmed on Vanuatu, entitled <i><a href="/wiki/Survivor:_Vanuatu" title="Survivor: Vanuatu">Survivor: Vanuatu</a> – Islands of Fire</i>. Two years later, Australia's <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celebrity_Survivor" title="Celebrity Survivor">Celebrity Survivor</a></i> was filmed at the same location used by the US version.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uatustats_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-uatustats-343">[343]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg/220px-Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg/330px-Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg/440px-Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Autumn_in_the_Dandenong_Ranges.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dandenong_Ranges" title="Dandenong Ranges">Dandenong Ranges</a> in <a href="/wiki/Victoria_(Australia)" title="Victoria (Australia)">Victoria</a> are popular among tourists.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Australia" title="Tourism in Australia">Tourism in Australia</a> is an important component of the Australian economy. In the financial year 2014/15, <a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">tourism</a> represented 3% of <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> contributing A$47.5 billion to the national economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABS1011_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-ABS1011-344">[344]</a></sup> In 2015, there were 7.4 million visitor arrivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-touraus181029_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-touraus181029-345">[345]</a></sup> Popular Australian destinations include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sydney_Harbour" title="Sydney Harbour">Sydney Harbour</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sydney_Opera_House" title="Sydney Opera House">Sydney Opera House</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Harbour_Bridge" title="Sydney Harbour Bridge">Sydney Harbour Bridge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Botanic_Garden,_Sydney" title="Royal Botanic Garden, Sydney">Royal Botanic Garden</a>, etc.), <a href="/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Queensland" title="Gold Coast, Queensland">Gold Coast</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theme_parks" title="Theme parks">theme parks</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Movie_World" title="Warner Bros. Movie World">Warner Bros. Movie World</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dreamworld_(Australian_theme_park)" title="Dreamworld (Australian theme park)">Dreamworld</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sea_World_(Australia)" title="Sea World (Australia)">Sea World</a>), <a href="/wiki/Walls_of_Jerusalem_National_Park" title="Walls of Jerusalem National Park">Walls of Jerusalem National Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Field_National_Park" title="Mount Field National Park">Mount Field National Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tasmania" title="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Exhibition_Building" title="Royal Exhibition Building">Royal Exhibition Building</a> in <a href="/wiki/Melbourne" title="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Barrier_Reef" title="Great Barrier Reef">Great Barrier Reef</a> in <a href="/wiki/Queensland" title="Queensland">Queensland</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Twelve_Apostles_(Victoria)" title="The Twelve Apostles (Victoria)">The Twelve Apostles</a> in <a href="/wiki/Victoria_(Australia)" title="Victoria (Australia)">Victoria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uluru" title="Uluru">Uluru</a> (Ayers Rock) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australian_outback" title="Australian outback">Australian outback</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausnatacc_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausnatacc-346">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_New_Zealand" title="Tourism in New Zealand">Tourism in New Zealand</a> contributes <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_dollar" title="New Zealand dollar">NZ$</a>7.3 billion (or 4%) of the country's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> in 2013, as well as directly supporting 110,800 full-time equivalent jobs (nearly 6% of New Zealand's workforce). International tourist spending accounted for 16% of New Zealand's export earnings (nearly NZ$10 billion). International and domestic tourism contributes, in total, NZ$24 billion to New Zealand's economy every year. <a href="/wiki/Tourism_New_Zealand" title="Tourism New Zealand">Tourism New Zealand</a>, the country's official tourism agency, is actively promoting the country as a destination worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minisbusi_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-minisbusi-347">[347]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Milford_Sound" title="Milford Sound">Milford Sound</a> in South Island is acclaimed as New Zealand's most famous tourist destination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SC_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-SC-348">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2003 alone, according to state government data, there were over 6.4 million <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Hawaii" title="Tourism in Hawaii">visitors to the Hawaiʻian Islands</a> with expenditures of over $10.6 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DBEDT_2003_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-DBEDT_2003-349">[349]</a></sup> Due to the mild year-round weather, tourist travel is popular throughout the year. In 2011, Hawaiʻi saw increasing arrivals and share of foreign tourists from Canada, Australia, and China increasing 13%, 24% and 21% respectively from 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hawasafe_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-hawasafe-350">[350]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Politics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia_3">Australia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Australia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Australia" title="Politics of Australia">Politics of Australia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prince_Charles_2012.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2072" data-file-width="1524" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Prince_Charles_2012.jpg/150px-Prince_Charles_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Prince_Charles_2012.jpg/225px-Prince_Charles_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Prince_Charles_2012.jpg/300px-Prince_Charles_2012.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prince_Charles_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Charles is <a href="/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth" title="Head of the Commonwealth">Head of the Commonwealth</a> and King of five Oceanian countries: Australia, New Zealand, <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tuvalu" title="Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Australia is a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausparliwork_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausparliwork-351">[351]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Charles_III" title="Charles III">Charles III</a> at its apex as the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Australia" title="Monarchy of Australia">King of Australia</a>, a role that is distinct from his position as monarch of the other <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">Commonwealth realms</a>. The King is represented in Australia by the <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Australia" title="Governor-General of Australia">Governor-General</a> at the federal level and by the <a href="/wiki/Governors_of_the_Australian_states" title="Governors of the Australian states">Governors</a> at the state level, who by convention act on the advice of his ministers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Davison_pp287–8_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-Davison_pp287–8-352">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govgenaus_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-govgenaus-353">[353]</a></sup> There are two major political groups that usually form government, federally and in the states: the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Labor_Party" title="Australian Labor Party">Australian Labor Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_(Australia)" title="Coalition (Australia)">Coalition</a> which is a formal grouping of the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Australia" title="Liberal Party of Australia">Liberal Party</a> and its minor partner, the <a href="/wiki/National_Party_of_Australia" title="National Party of Australia">National Party</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-glosselec_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-glosselec-354">[354]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statepar_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-statepar-355">[355]</a></sup> Within Australian political culture, the Coalition is considered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre-right" title="Centre-right">centre-right</a> and the Labor Party is considered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centre-left" title="Centre-left">centre-left</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govpol2013_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-govpol2013-356">[356]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Australian_Defence_Force" title="Australian Defence Force">Australian Defence Force</a> is by far the largest military force in Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-defenceann_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-defenceann-357">[357]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Zealand_2">New Zealand</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: New Zealand">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_New_Zealand" title="Politics of New Zealand">Politics of New Zealand</a></div>
<p>New Zealand is a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GG_constitution_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-GG_constitution-358">[358]</a></sup> although <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_New_Zealand" title="Constitution of New Zealand">its constitution</a> is <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">not codified</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_factsheet_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-Economist_factsheet-359">[359]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Charles_III" title="Charles III">Charles III</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_New_Zealand" title="Monarchy of New Zealand">King of New Zealand</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-royalt1974_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-royalt1974-360">[360]</a></sup> The King is represented by the <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_New_Zealand" title="Governor-General of New Zealand">Governor-General</a>, whom he appoints on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Advice_(constitutional)" title="Advice (constitutional)">advice</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand" title="Prime Minister of New Zealand">Prime Minister</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rolegg_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-rolegg-361">[361]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Parliament" title="New Zealand Parliament">New Zealand Parliament</a> holds <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_power" title="Legislative power">legislative power</a> and consists of the King and the <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_House_of_Representatives" title="New Zealand House of Representatives">House of Representatives</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament_facts_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-parliament_facts-362">[362]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_New_Zealand" title="Elections in New Zealand">parliamentary general election</a> must be called no later than three years after the previous election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eleccyc_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-eleccyc-363">[363]</a></sup> New Zealand is identified as one of the world's most stable and well-governed states,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fragileind16_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-fragileind16-364">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-demoindex16_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-demoindex16-365">[365]</a></sup> with high government transparency and among the lowest perceived levels of corruption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transpint201116_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-transpint201116-366">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pacific_Islands_2">Pacific Islands</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Pacific Islands">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}html.client-js body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Expand_section plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg"><img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/></a></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs expansion</b>. You can help by <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">adding to it</a>.  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2018</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1093" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG/250px-Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG/375px-Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG/500px-Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Samoa_government_building_2010.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Government building in the Samoan capital <a href="/wiki/Apia" title="Apia">Apia</a> housing administrative ministerial offices.</div></div></div>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Samoa" title="Politics of Samoa">Samoan politics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Samoa" title="Prime Minister of Samoa">Prime Minister of Samoa</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Samoa" title="Constitution of Samoa">1960 constitution</a>, which formally came into force with independence from New Zealand in 1962, builds on the British pattern of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a>, modified to take account of Samoan customs. The national government (<i>malo</i>) generally controls the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Samoa" title="Legislative Assembly of Samoa">legislative assembly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-backnotes_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-backnotes-367">[367]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Tonga" title="Politics of Tonga">Politics of Tonga</a> takes place in a framework of a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, whereby the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_of_Tonga" title="King of Tonga">King of Tonga</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Head_of_State" title="Head of State">Head of State</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Fiji" title="Politics of Fiji">Fiji</a> has a multiparty system with the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Fiji" title="Prime Minister of Fiji">Prime Minister of Fiji</a> as head of government. The <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive power</a> is exercised by the government. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_power" title="Legislative power">Legislative power</a> is vested in both the government and the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Fiji" title="Parliament of Fiji">Parliament of Fiji</a>. <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Head_of_State_of_Fiji" title="Head of State of Fiji">Head of State</a> is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Fiji" title="President of Fiji">President</a>. He is elected by <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Fiji" title="Parliament of Fiji">Parliament of Fiji</a> after nomination by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Fiji" title="Prime Minister of Fiji">Prime Minister</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Opposition_(Fiji)" title="Leader of the Opposition (Fiji)">Leader of the Opposition</a>, for a three-year term.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Papua_New_Guinea" title="Politics of Papua New Guinea">politics of Papua New Guinea</a> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_the_Papua_New_Guinea" title="List of Prime Ministers of the Papua New Guinea">Prime Minister</a> is the head of government, and the head of state is <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">the monarch of the United Kingdom</a>, represented by a <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_Papua_New_Guinea" title="Governor-General of Papua New Guinea">Governor-General</a>. In <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Kiribati" title="Politics of Kiribati">Kiribati</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">Parliamentary regime</a>, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Kiribati" title="President of Kiribati">President of Kiribati</a> is the head of state and government, and of a multi-party system.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_New_Caledonia" title="Politics of New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> remains an integral part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Republic" title="French Republic">French Republic</a>. Inhabitants of New Caledonia are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_citizen" title="French citizen">French citizens</a> and carry French passports. They take part in the legislative and presidential French elections. New Caledonia sends two representatives to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_National_Assembly" title="French National Assembly">French National Assembly</a> and two senators to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_Senate" title="French Senate">French Senate</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Hawaii" title="Politics of Hawaii">Hawaiʻi</a> is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a>. As codified in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Hawaii" title="Constitution of Hawaii">Hawaiʻian Constitution</a>, there are three <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Branches_of_government" title="Branches of government">branches of government</a>: executive, legislative and judicial. The governor is elected statewide. The lieutenant governor acts as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_Hawaii" title="Secretary of State of Hawaii">Secretary of State</a>. The governor and lieutenant governor oversee twenty agencies and departments from offices in the <a href="/wiki/Hawaii_State_Capitol" title="Hawaii State Capitol">State Capitol</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Australia_4">Australia</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Australia">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Australia" title="Culture of Australia">Culture of Australia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_Australia" title="Cuisine of Australia">Cuisine of Australia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sydney_Opera_House,_botanic_gardens_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1470" data-file-width="2233" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Sydney_Opera_House%2C_botanic_gardens_1.jpg/220px-Sydney_Opera_House%2C_botanic_gardens_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Sydney_Opera_House%2C_botanic_gardens_1.jpg/330px-Sydney_Opera_House%2C_botanic_gardens_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Sydney_Opera_House%2C_botanic_gardens_1.jpg/440px-Sydney_Opera_House%2C_botanic_gardens_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sydney_Opera_House,_botanic_gardens_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>On 28 June 2007, the Sydney Opera House became a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-operawin_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-operawin-368">[368]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since 1788, the primary influence behind Australian culture has been <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Celtic" title="Anglo-Celtic">Anglo-Celtic</a> <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a>, with some <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Australians" title="Indigenous Australians">Indigenous</a> influences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jupp769_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-jupp769-369">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-twhite118_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-twhite118-370">[370]</a></sup> The divergence and evolution that has occurred in the ensuing centuries has resulted in a distinctive Australian culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Davison_pp98–9_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-Davison_pp98–9-371">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-twhite125_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-twhite125-372">[372]</a></sup> Since the mid-20th century, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">American popular culture</a> has strongly influenced Australia, particularly through television and cinema.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tw_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-tw-373">[373]</a></sup> Other cultural influences come from neighbouring Asian countries, and through large-scale immigration from non-English-speaking nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tw_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-tw-373">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jupp74_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-jupp74-374">[374]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Story_of_the_Kelly_Gang" title="The Story of the Kelly Gang">The Story of the Kelly Gang</a></i> (1906), the world's first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feature_length" title="Feature length">feature length</a> film, spurred a boom in <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Australia" title="Cinema of Australia">Australian cinema</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent film</a> era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kellyg07_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-kellyg07-375">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wavefilm_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-wavefilm-376">[376]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Australian_Museum" title="Australian Museum">Australian Museum</a> in Sydney and the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Victoria" title="National Gallery of Victoria">National Gallery of Victoria</a> in Melbourne are the oldest and <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_art_museums" title="List of largest art museums">largest</a> <a href="/wiki/Museum" title="Museum">museums</a> in Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausmuseum_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausmuseum-377">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VHR_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-VHR-378">[378]</a></sup> The city's <a href="/wiki/Sydney_New_Year%27s_Eve" title="Sydney New Year's Eve">New Year's Eve</a> celebrations are the largest in Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auseve2013_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-auseve2013-379">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>Australia is also known for its <a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">cafe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coffee_culture" title="Coffee culture">coffee culture</a> in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban centres</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abcnet160511_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-abcnet160511-380">[380]</a></sup> Australia and <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> were responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Flat_white" title="Flat white">flat white</a> coffee. Most Indigenous Australian tribal groups subsisted on a simple <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer_diet" title="Hunter-gatherer diet">hunter-gatherer diet</a> of native fauna and flora, otherwise called <a href="/wiki/Bush_tucker" title="Bush tucker">bush tucker</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bushtpb_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-bushtpb-381">[381]</a></sup> The first settlers introduced <a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British food</a> to the continent, much of which is now considered typical Australian food, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sunday_roast" title="Sunday roast">Sunday roast</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-food_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-food-382">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-f2_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-f2-383">[383]</a></sup> Multicultural immigration transformed Australian cuisine; post-World War II European migrants, particularly from the Mediterranean, helped to build a thriving Australian <a href="/wiki/Coffee_culture" title="Coffee culture">coffee culture</a>, and the influence of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Asia" title="Culture of Asia">Asian cultures</a> has led to Australian variants of their staple foods, such as the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">Chinese</a>-inspired <a href="/wiki/Dim_sim" title="Dim sim">dim sim</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chiko_Roll" title="Chiko Roll">Chiko Roll</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kangcww1999_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-kangcww1999-384">[384]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iolani_Palace_(1328).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="743" data-file-width="967" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Iolani_Palace_%281328%29.JPG/220px-Iolani_Palace_%281328%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Iolani_Palace_%281328%29.JPG/330px-Iolani_Palace_%281328%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Iolani_Palace_%281328%29.JPG/440px-Iolani_Palace_%281328%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iolani_Palace_(1328).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iolani_Palace" title="Iolani Palace">ʻIolani Palace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Honolulu" title="Honolulu">Honolulu</a>, formerly the residence of the Hawaiʻian monarch, was restored and opened to the public as a museum in 1978.</div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Hawai.CA.BBi"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hawaiʻi">Hawaiʻi</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Hawaiʻi">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Culture_of_Hawaii" title="Culture of Hawaii">Culture of Hawaii</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_Hawaii" title="Cuisine of Hawaii">Cuisine of Hawaii</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_religion" title="Hawaiian religion">Hawaiian religion</a></div>
<p>The music of Hawaiʻi includes traditional and popular styles, ranging from native Hawaiʻian folk music to modern <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>. Hawaiʻi's musical contributions to the <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">music of the United States</a> are out of proportion to the state's small size. Styles such as <a href="/wiki/Slack-key_guitar" title="Slack-key guitar">slack-key guitar</a> are well known worldwide, while Hawaiʻian-tinged music is a frequent part of <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">Hollywood</a> soundtracks. Hawaiʻi also made a major contribution to <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country music</a> with the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Steel_guitar" title="Steel guitar">steel guitar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unterberger_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unterberger-385">[385]</a></sup> The Hawaiʻian religion is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polytheistic" title="Polytheistic">polytheistic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Animistic" title="Animistic">animistic</a>, with a belief in many deities and spirits, including the belief that spirits are found in non-human beings and objects such as animals, the waves, and the sky.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chai_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chai-386">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_Hawaii" title="Cuisine of Hawaii">cuisine of Hawaiʻi</a> is a fusion of many foods brought by immigrants to the Hawaiʻian Islands, including the earliest Polynesians and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Native_Hawaiian_cuisine" title="Native Hawaiian cuisine">native Hawaiʻians</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States" title="Cuisine of the United States">American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Filipino_cuisine" title="Filipino cuisine">Filipino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">Japanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_cuisine" title="Korean cuisine">Korean</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polynesian_cuisine" title="Polynesian cuisine">Polynesian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_cuisine" title="Portuguese cuisine">Portuguese</a> origins. Native Hawaiʻian musician and Hawaiʻian sovereignty activist <a href="/wiki/Israel_Kamakawiwo%CA%BBole" title="Israel Kamakawiwoʻole">Israel Kamakawiwoʻole</a>, famous for his medley of "<a href="/wiki/Somewhere_Over_the_Rainbow/What_a_Wonderful_World" title="Somewhere Over the Rainbow/What a Wonderful World">Somewhere Over the Rainbow/What a Wonderful World</a>", was named "The Voice of Hawaii" by <a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">NPR</a> in 2010 in its 50 great voices series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npr101206_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-npr101206-387">[387]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Zealand_3">New Zealand</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: New Zealand">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_New_Zealand" title="Culture of New Zealand">Culture of New Zealand</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_New_Zealand" title="Cuisine of New Zealand">Cuisine of New Zealand</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg"><img alt="Hills with inset, round doors. Reflected in water." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg/220px-Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg/330px-Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg/440px-Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hobbit_holes_reflected_in_water.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Hobbiton_Movie_Set" title="Hobbiton Movie Set">Hobbiton Movie Set</a>, located near <a href="/wiki/Matamata" title="Matamata">Matamata</a>, was used for <i>The Lord of the Rings</i> film trilogy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hobbitset_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-hobbitset-388">[388]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New Zealand as a culture is a Western culture, which is influenced by the cultural input of the indigenous <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people" title="Māori people">Māori</a> and the various waves of multi-ethnic migration which followed the <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_Zealand" title="History of New Zealand">British colonisation of New Zealand</a>. The Māori people constitute one of the major cultures of Polynesia. The country has been broadened by globalisation and immigration specifically from Oceania, Europe, and Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natdays_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-natdays-389">[389]</a></sup> New Zealand marks two national days of remembrance, <a href="/wiki/Waitangi_Day" title="Waitangi Day">Waitangi Day</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ANZAC_Day" title="ANZAC Day">ANZAC Day</a>, and also celebrates many holidays such as the Queen's Birthday, Labour Day, and Christmas Day, as well as public anniversaries of the founding dates of most regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govnathol_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-govnathol-390">[390]</a></sup> The New Zealand recording industry began to develop from 1940 onwards and many New Zealand musicians have obtained success in Britain and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-music-391">[391]</a></sup> Some artists release Māori language songs and the Māori tradition-based art of <i><a href="/wiki/Kapa_haka" title="Kapa haka">kapa haka</a></i> (song and dance) has made a resurgence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-create062010_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-create062010-392">[392]</a></sup> The country's diverse scenery and compact size, plus government incentives,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt101028_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt101028-393">[393]</a></sup> have encouraged some <a href="/wiki/Film_producer" title="Film producer">producers</a> to film big budget movies in New Zealand, including <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">Avatar</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" title="The Lord of the Rings (film series)">The Lord of the Rings</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hobbit_(film_series)" title="The Hobbit (film series)">The Hobbit</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_(film_series)" title="The Chronicles of Narnia (film series)">The Chronicles of Narnia</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/King_Kong_(2005_film)" title="King Kong (2005 film)">King Kong</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Samurai" title="The Last Samurai">The Last Samurai</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-filmnz_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-filmnz-394">[394]</a></sup>
</p><p>The national cuisine has been described as <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Rim" title="Pacific Rim">Pacific Rim</a>, incorporating the native <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_cuisine" title="Māori cuisine">Māori cuisine</a> and diverse culinary traditions introduced by settlers and immigrants from Europe, Polynesia and Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-395">[395]</a></sup> New Zealand yields produce from land and sea – most crops and livestock, such as maize, potatoes and pigs, were gradually introduced by the early European settlers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kaipakeha_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-kaipakeha-396">[396]</a></sup> Distinctive ingredients or dishes include <a href="/wiki/Lamb_and_mutton" title="Lamb and mutton">lamb</a>; salmon; <a href="/wiki/Paranephrops" title="Paranephrops">koura</a> (crayfish);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encyclnzshell_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-encyclnzshell-397">[397]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Whitebait" title="Whitebait">whitebait</a>; shellfish including <a href="/wiki/Dredge_oyster" title="Dredge oyster">dredge oysters</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paua" title="Paua">paua</a>, mussels, scallops, <a href="/wiki/Paphies_australis" title="Paphies australis">pipi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tuatua" title="Tuatua">tuatua</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ecyclnzshell222_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-ecyclnzshell222-398">[398]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sweet_potato" title="Sweet potato">kumara</a> (sweet potato); <a href="/wiki/Kiwifruit" title="Kiwifruit">kiwifruit</a>; <a href="/wiki/Tamarillo" title="Tamarillo">tamarillo</a>; and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pavlova_(food)" title="Pavlova (food)">pavlova</a> (considered a national dish).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encyclnzcook_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-encyclnzcook-399">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuisine_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-cuisine-395">[395]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Samoa">Samoa</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Samoa">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg/220px-Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg/330px-Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg/440px-Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fale_on_Manono_Island.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Samoa" title="Architecture of Samoa">fale</a> on <a href="/wiki/Manono_Island" title="Manono Island">Manono Island</a></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Samoa" title="Culture of Samoa">Culture of Samoa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_culture" title="Polynesian culture">Polynesian culture</a></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fa%27a_Samoa" title="Fa'a Samoa">fa'a Samoa</a>, or traditional Samoan way, remains a strong force in Samoan life and politics. Despite centuries of European influence, Samoa maintains its historical customs, social and political systems, and <a href="/wiki/Samoan_language" title="Samoan language">language</a>. Cultural customs such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samoa_%27ava_ceremony" title="Samoa 'ava ceremony">Samoa 'ava ceremony</a> are significant and solemn rituals at important occasions including the bestowal of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fa%27amatai" title="Fa'amatai">matai</a></i> chiefly titles. Items of great cultural value include the finely woven <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%27ie_toga" title="'ie toga">'ie toga</a></i>.
</p><p>The Samoan word for dance is <i><a href="/wiki/Siva_Samoa" title="Siva Samoa">siva</a></i>, which consists of unique gentle movements of the body in time to music and which tell a story. Samoan male dances can be more snappy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dancesiva_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-dancesiva-400">[400]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Sasa_(dance)" title="Sasa (dance)">sasa</a></i> is also a traditional dance where rows of dancers perform rapid <a href="/wiki/Synchronization" title="Synchronization">synchronised</a> movements in time to the rhythm of wooden drums <i>(<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pate_(musical_instrument)" title="Pate (musical instrument)">pate</a>)</i> or rolled mats. Another dance performed by males is called the <i><a href="/wiki/Fa%27ataupati" title="Fa'ataupati">fa'ataupati</a></i> or the slap dance, creating rhythmic sounds by slapping different parts of the body. As with other Polynesian cultures (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hawaiian_culture" title="Hawaiian culture">Hawaiʻian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tahitians" title="Tahitians">Tahitian</a> and <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_culture" title="Māori culture">Māori</a>) with significant and unique tattoos, Samoans have two gender specific and culturally significant tattoos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wwpride_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-wwpride-401">[401]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Arts">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Oceanian_art" title="Oceanian art">Oceanian art</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samoan_art" title="Samoan art">Samoan art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_art" title="Hawaiian art">Hawaiian art</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_art" title="Māori art">Māori art</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_Australian_art" title="Indigenous Australian art">Indigenous Australian art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg/230px-Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg/345px-Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg/460px-Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg 2x" width="230"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bradshaw_rock_paintings.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Gwion_Gwion_rock_paintings" title="Gwion Gwion rock paintings">Gwion Gwion rock paintings</a> found in the north-west <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kimberley_region_of_Western_Australia" title="Kimberley region of Western Australia">Kimberley region of Western Australia</a></div></div></div>
<p>The artistic creations of native Oceanians varies greatly throughout the cultures and regions. The subject matter typically carries themes of fertility or the supernatural.
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Petroglyphs" title="Petroglyphs">Petroglyphs</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tattooing" title="Tattooing">tattooing</a>, painting, wood carving, stone carving, and textile work are other common art forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artino_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-artino-402">[402]</a></sup> Art of Oceania properly encompasses the artistic traditions of the people indigenous to Australia and the Pacific Islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oce_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-oce-403">[403]</a></sup> These early peoples lacked a <a href="/wiki/Writing_system" title="Writing system">writing system</a>, and made works on perishable materials, so few records of them exist from this time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mettime_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-mettime-404">[404]</a></sup>
</p><p>Indigenous Australian <a href="/wiki/Rock_art" title="Rock art">rock art</a> is the oldest and richest unbroken tradition of art in the world, dating as far back as 60,000 years and spread across hundreds of thousands of sites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rockart531_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-rockart531-405">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt051106_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt051106-406">[406]</a></sup> These rock paintings served several functions. Some were used in magic, others to increase animal populations for hunting, while some were simply for amusement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mettime4_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-mettime4-407">[407]</a></sup> Sculpture in Oceania first appears on New Guinea as a series of stone figures found throughout the island, but mostly in mountainous highlands. Establishing a chronological timeframe for these pieces in most cases is difficult, but one has been dated to <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1500 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mettime444_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-mettime444-408">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1500 BCE the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lapita" title="Lapita">Lapita</a> culture, descendants of the second wave, would begin to expand and spread into the more remote islands. At around the same time, art began to appear in New Guinea, including the earliest examples of sculpture in Oceania. Beginning <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1100 CE, the people of Easter Island would begin construction of nearly 900 <a href="/wiki/Moai" title="Moai">moai</a> (large stone statues). At <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1200 CE, the people of Pohnpei, a Micronesian island, would embark on another megalithic construction, building <a href="/wiki/Nan_Madol" title="Nan Madol">Nan Madol</a>, a city of artificial islands and a system of canals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mettime_453_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-mettime_453-409">[409]</a></sup> Hawaiʻian art includes <a href="/wiki/Wood_carving" title="Wood carving">wood carvings</a>, feather work, petroglyphs, bark cloth (called <a href="/wiki/Kapa" title="Kapa">kapa</a> in Hawaiʻian and <a href="/wiki/Tapa_cloth" title="Tapa cloth">tapa</a> elsewhere in the Pacific), and tattoos. Native Hawaiʻians had neither metal nor woven cloth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mettime3456_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-mettime3456-410">[410]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Sport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Oceania" title="Sport in Oceania">Sport in Oceania</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg/220px-Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg/330px-Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg/440px-Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fiji_vs_Wales_CG_Melbourne_2006.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fiji playing <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_rugby_sevens_team" title="Wales national rugby sevens team">Wales</a> at <a href="/wiki/Rugby_sevens" title="Rugby sevens">seven-a-side rugby</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">Rugby union</a> is one of the region's most prominent sports,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ocerugb_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-ocerugb-411">[411]</a></sup> and is the national sport of New Zealand, Samoa, Fiji and Tonga. The most popular overall sport in Australia is <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a>, with their <a href="/wiki/Australia_national_cricket_team" title="Australia national cricket team">national team</a> having won the <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a> a record five times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup> The most popular sport among Australian women is <a href="/wiki/Netball" title="Netball">netball</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Australian_rules_football" title="Australian rules football">Australian rules football</a> garners the highest spectatorship numbers and television ratings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausrulebrit_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausrulebrit-413">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aust54_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-aust54-414">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-planetsp85_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-planetsp85-415">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aust101_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-aust101-416">[416]</a></sup> Rugby union is the most popular sport among New Zealanders,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newzea76_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-newzea76-417">[417]</a></sup> and they are tied with <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> for the most <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">Rugby World Cup</a> titles, having won the tournament three times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup> Australia's team <a href="/wiki/Australia_national_rugby_union_team" title="Australia national rugby union team">the Wallbies</a> have also managed to win the World Cup twice, despite Rugby union being less popular among Australians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup> In Papua New Guinea, the most popular sport is <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">Rugby league</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rl_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-rl-420">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rugby66_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-rugby66-421">[421]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fiji_national_rugby_sevens_team" title="Fiji national rugby sevens team">Fiji's sevens team</a> is one of the most successful in the world, as is <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_sevens_team" title="New Zealand national rugby sevens team">New Zealand's</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-southemiclass_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-southemiclass-422">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>Australian rules football is the national sport in <a href="/wiki/Australian_rules_football_in_Nauru" title="Australian rules football in Nauru">Nauru</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-naurafl_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-naurafl-423">[423]</a></sup> It has a large following in Papua New Guinea, where it is the second most popular sport after Rugby League.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-miningpapua_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-miningpapua-424">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msnclosure_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-msnclosure-425">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-footinaus_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-footinaus-426">[426]</a></sup> Additionally, it attracts significant attention across New Zealand and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands" title="Pacific Islands">Pacific Islands</a>. The highest level of the sport is the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Football_League" title="Australian Football League">Australian Football League</a> (AFL), which was the fourth best attended sporting league in the world during the 2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Football_in_Vanuatu" title="Football in Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a> is the only country in Oceania to call <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a> its national sport. However, it is also the most popular sport in <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Kiribati" title="Football in Kiribati">Kiribati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Solomon_Islands" title="Football in Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Tuvalu" title="Football in Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a>, and has a significant (and growing) popularity in <a href="/wiki/Soccer_in_Australia" title="Soccer in Australia">Australia</a>. In 2006 Australia left the <a href="/wiki/Oceania_Football_Confederation" title="Oceania Football Confederation">Oceania Football Confederation</a> (OFC) for the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation" title="Asian Football Confederation">Asian Football Confederation</a> (AFC), and their men's team <a href="/wiki/Australia_men%27s_national_soccer_team" title="Australia men's national soccer team">the Socceroos</a> have qualified for every subsequent <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> as an Asian entrant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fifa2010_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-fifa2010-428">[428]</a></sup> The sole Micronesian country with membership in the OFC is Kiribati, although they are not recognized by <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a> like the other OFC members. <a href="/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia_national_football_team" title="Federated States of Micronesia national football team">Federated States of Micronesia</a>, Marshall Islands, Nauru and <a href="/wiki/Palau_national_football_team" title="Palau national football team">Palau</a> all have no presence, primarily due to lack of infrastructure and logistical difficulties related to Micronesia's remoteness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Associate_Members_of_OFC_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-Associate_Members_of_OFC-430">[430]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup> Like Australia, the Micronesian dependent territories of <a href="/wiki/Guam_national_football_team" title="Guam national football team">Guam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands_national_football_team" title="Northern Mariana Islands national football team">Northern Mariana Islands</a> currently compete in the AFC instead of the OFC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup> The OFC was dominated by Australia for many years, and became known for one-sided results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsc_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsc-433">[433]</a></sup> These included a <a href="/wiki/Australia_31%E2%80%930_American_Samoa" title="Australia 31–0 American Samoa">31–0 defeat</a> of <a href="/wiki/American_Samoa_national_football_team" title="American Samoa national football team">American Samoa</a> by Australia in 2001, which remains the biggest international victory in the history of the sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup> It broke the previous record set two days earlier when Australia <a href="/wiki/Tonga_0%E2%80%9322_Australia" title="Tonga 0–22 Australia">defeated Tonga 22–0</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p>Australians view sport as an important part of their cultural identity, and the country performs well on the international stage, despite having a relatively small population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[438]</a></sup> They have hosted two Summer Olympics: <a href="/wiki/1956_Summer_Olympics" title="1956 Summer Olympics">Melbourne 1956</a> and <a href="/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics" title="2000 Summer Olympics">Sydney 2000</a>, and the city of Brisbane is also set to host the <a href="/wiki/2032_Summer_Olympics" title="2032 Summer Olympics">2032 edition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[439]</a></sup> Australia (and New Zealand) were among the small handful of non-<a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> countries who decided to participate at <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics" title="1980 Summer Olympics">Moscow 1980</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[440]</a></sup> Additionally, Australia has hosted five editions of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">Commonwealth Games</a> (<a href="/wiki/1938_British_Empire_Games" title="1938 British Empire Games">Sydney 1938</a>, <a href="/wiki/1962_British_Empire_and_Commonwealth_Games" title="1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games">Perth 1962</a>, <a href="/wiki/1982_Commonwealth_Games" title="1982 Commonwealth Games">Brisbane 1982</a>, <a href="/wiki/2006_Commonwealth_Games" title="2006 Commonwealth Games">Melbourne 2006</a>, <a href="/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games" title="2018 Commonwealth Games">Gold Coast 2018</a>). Meanwhile, New Zealand has hosted the Commonwealth Games three times: <a href="/wiki/1950_British_Empire_Games" title="1950 British Empire Games">Auckland 1950</a>, <a href="/wiki/1974_British_Commonwealth_Games" title="1974 British Commonwealth Games">Christchurch 1974</a> and <a href="/wiki/1990_Commonwealth_Games" title="1990 Commonwealth Games">Auckland 1990</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Games" title="Pacific Games">Pacific Games</a> (formerly known as the South Pacific Games) is a multi-sport event, much like the Olympics on a much smaller scale, with participation exclusively from countries around the Pacific. It is held every four years and began in 1963.
Australia and New Zealand competed in the games for the first time in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abc20140703_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-abc20140703-441">[441]</a></sup>
</p><p>Melbourne hosts the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> every year, considered one of the four major <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tournaments in <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>. It was held for the first time in 1905.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oceania&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">

<li id="cite_note-aging-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-aging_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-aging_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFlickerKerse2017">Flicker, Leon; Kerse, Ngaire (2017). "Population ageing in Oceania". <a class="external text" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/345701209" rel="nofollow"><i>Oxford Textbook of Geriatric Medicine</i></a>. Oxford University Press. <q>The region of Oceania describes a collection of islands scattered throughout the Pacific Ocean between Asia and the Americas. The region is vast and largely covered by ocean. There are four subregions of this region including Australasia (Australia and New Zealand), Melanesia (Papua and New Guinea, Fiji, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, and New Caledonia), Micronesia (Federated States of Micronesia and Guam), and Polynesia (includes French Polynesia, Samoa, Tonga, Tokalau, and Niue).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Population+ageing+in+Oceania&amp;rft.btitle=Oxford+Textbook+of+Geriatric+Medicine&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.aulast=Flicker&amp;rft.aufirst=Leon&amp;rft.au=Kerse%2C+Ngaire&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.researchgate.net%2Fpublication%2F345701209&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AOceania"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-herita-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-herita_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.heritage.org/index/ranking" rel="nofollow">"Rankings on Economic Freedom"</a>. <a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a>. 2016. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170916153902/http://www.heritage.org/index/ranking" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 16 September 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 November</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Rankings+on+Economic+Freedom&amp;rft.pub=The+Heritage+Foundation&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.heritage.org%2Findex%2Franking&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AOceania"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-imforg-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-imforg_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/cat/longres.aspx?sk=24871.0" rel="nofollow">"Kiribati: 2011 Article IV Consultation-Staff Report, Informational Annexes, Debt Sustainability Analysis, Public Information Notice on the Executive Board Discussion, and Statement by the Executive Director for Kiribati"</a>. International Monetary Fund Country Report No. 11/113. 24 May 2011. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161224064230/https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/cat/longres.aspx?sk=24871.0" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 24 December 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-newpol162-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-newpol162_17-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDrage1994">Drage, Jean (1994). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ZUpmpeJz-8gC" rel="nofollow"><i>New Politics in the South pacific</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLidstoneStoltmanDeChano2004">Lidstone, John; Stoltman, Joseph P.; DeChano, Lisa M. (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/International_Perspectives_on_Natural_Di/94q9GgFtjYoC?hl=en&amp;gbpv=1&amp;dq=%22and+Melanesia,+meaning%22&amp;pg=PA193&amp;printsec=frontcover" rel="nofollow"><i>International Perspectives on Natural Disasters: Occurrence, Mitigation, and Consequences</i></a>. Springer Netherlands. p. 193. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781402028519" title="Special:BookSources/9781402028519"><bdi>9781402028519</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220730064235/https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/International_Perspectives_on_Natural_Di/94q9GgFtjYoC?hl=en&amp;gbpv=1&amp;dq=%22and+Melanesia%2C+meaning%22&amp;pg=PA193&amp;printsec=frontcover" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 30 July 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 July</span> 2022</span>. <q>Anthropologists have defined Oceania as that region of the Pacific Ocean that encompasses three distinct geographical areas—Polynesia, meaning "many islands"; Micronesia, meaning "small islands"; and Melanesia, meaning "black islands". Other definitions of Oceania are used by geographers, economists, and oceanographers. The definition of the region generally depends on the context that one assigns to it in research or writing.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=International+Perspectives+on+Natural+Disasters%3A+Occurrence%2C+Mitigation%2C+and+Consequences&amp;rft.pages=193&amp;rft.pub=Springer+Netherlands&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=9781402028519&amp;rft.aulast=Lidstone&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.au=Stoltman%2C+Joseph+P.&amp;rft.au=DeChano%2C+Lisa+M.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com.au%2Fbooks%2Fedition%2FInternational_Perspectives_on_Natural_Di%2F94q9GgFtjYoC%3Fhl%3Den%26gbpv%3D1%26dq%3D%2522and%2BMelanesia%2C%2Bmeaning%2522%26pg%3DPA193%26printsec%3Dfrontcover&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AOceania"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-asianpacific-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-asianpacific_19-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-asianpacific_19-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-asianpacific_19-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCrocombe2007">Crocombe, R. G. (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=iDg9oAkwsXAC&amp;dq=%22included+in+cultural+definitions+of+oceania%22&amp;pg=PR13" rel="nofollow"><i>Asia in the Pacific Islands: Replacing the West</i></a>. University of the South Pacific. Institute of Pacific Studies. p. 13. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9789820203884" title="Special:BookSources/9789820203884"><bdi>9789820203884</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220209001401/https://books.google.com/books?id=iDg9oAkwsXAC&amp;dq=%22included+in+cultural+definitions+of+oceania%22&amp;pg=PR13" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 9 February 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Oceania-region-Pacific-Ocean" rel="nofollow">"Oceania | Definition, Population, &amp; Facts | Britannica"</a>. <i>Britannica.com</i>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080531185210/https://www.britannica.com/place/Oceania-region-Pacific-Ocean" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 31 May 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 July</span> 2022</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Britannica.com&amp;rft.atitle=Oceania+%26%23124%3B+Definition%2C+Population%2C+%26+Facts+%26%23124%3B+Britannica&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fplace%2FOceania-region-Pacific-Ocean&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AOceania"></span></span>
